Necrothesp moved page [[James Grant (Texas)]] to [[James Grant (Texas politician)]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= James Grant |image= |caption= James Grant |birth_date= July 28, 1793 |death_date={{death date and age|1836|3|2|1793|7|28}} |birth_place= Ross-shire, [[Scotland]] |death_place= Agua Dulce, [[Nueces County, Texas]] |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |nickname= |allegiance= {{flag|Republic of Texas}} |branch={{flagicon|Republic of Texas}} [[Texian Army]] |serviceyears= 1835-36 |rank= Private
Co-commander |unit= |commands= |battles=[[Texas Revolution]] *[[Siege of Bexar]] *[[Battle of Agua Dulce]]{{KIA}} |awards= |relations= |laterwork= }} '''James Grant''' (1793–1836) was a 19th-century Texas politician, physician and military participant in the Texas Revolution. ==Early life== James Grant was born on July 28, 1793, in Ross-shire, Scotland, son of William Grant. His paternal grandfather, Alexander Grant, was a veteran of the [[battle of Culloden]] of 1746 who later became a director of the [[East India Company]] and was the last man to escape from the [[Black Hole of Calcutta]].Reid (2007), p. 13. Grant attended medical school, and in 1812 he joined the East India Company. Despite his young age, with the influence of his cousin [[Charles Grant, 1st Baron Glenelg]], he was named the surgeon for the ''General Stuart''. Just before leaving on his maiden voyage, Grant married Margaret Urquhart, the daughter of an East India Company official.Reid (2007), p. 14. Over the next seven years, Grant made three voyages with the East India Company to India and to China. In a brief visit home, he fathered a son, Stewart Majoribanks, who was born in 1817. His daughter Jamesina was born five years later. On his voyages, Grant, like most of his comrades, did a little trading of his own, resulting in a respectable fortune. In 1823, he traveled to northern Mexico, ending up in Texas. He became interested in real estate and purchased an estate in Parras, Coahuila, Mexico in 1825.Thomas W. Cutrer, "TOLER, DANIEL J.", Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fto11], accessed June 10, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association. In Coahuila, he was soon involved in politics, where he became secretary of the Executive Council. In 1832, he was a member of the legislature of [[Coahuila and Texas]].Robert Bruce Blake, "GRANT, JAMES", Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fgr12], accessed June 09, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association. In 1832 and 1833, he tried his hand in colonizing a settlement near [[Goliad]]. In 1833, Grant moved to [[Nacogdoches]], Texas. From March through April, 1835, Grant was secretary of the legislature of Coahuila and Texas at Monclova, Mexico. In Coahuila, he acquired vast landholdings and was friends to the Federalist Mexicans and enemies to the Centralists. In 1834 and 1835 he was "Jefe de Armas" or Commander of the local military police. In the spring of 1836, Grant and the Mexican legislators were forced to flee Coahuila when President [[Antonio López de Santa Anna|Santa Anna]] sent General [[Martín Perfecto de Cos]] with a regiment of the Mexican army to disperse the congress. ==Texas Revolution== He was soon a member of the [[Texian Army]], serving from December 1835 through March 1836, during the [[Texas Revolution]] and fighting in the [[Siege of Bexar]].Hardin (1994), p. 78. In San Antonio, he would help plan the assault on BexarSantos (1968), p. 5. and negotiate the surrender of Cos. He served as a Goliad delegate to the [[Consultation (Texas)|Consultation]]. In early December, Grant was advocating for an expedition to invade [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros]], suggesting Houston was not the person to be in charge of the Texian Army.Hardin (1994), p. 107. By January 10, 1836, Grant and [[Frank W. Johnson]], who were old partners in Monclova land deals, were seeking volunteers to join a Federal Volunteer Army of Texas to march on Matamoros.Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 30. On January 14, [[Sam Houston]] arrived in Goliad to take command of the army that Grant and Johnson had recruited. He soon discovered that Grant and Johnson had established themselves as commanders of the army. Houston went along with the Texian army, instilling camaraderie as they reached [[Refugio, Texas]]. In Refugio he approached the soldiers, telling them how a small army could not conquer a city of 12,000 and thereby convinced over half of the men to quit. That same day, Houston would receive word that he had been removed by the council as commander of the army and had been replaced by [[James Fannin]]. Houston left the army and traveled to negotiate with the [[Cherokee]]s in the [[East Texas|eastern]] region of Texas.Hardin (1994), p. 110. For several months it was unclear if Grant, Fannin, Johnson, or Houston was in charge of the Texian army. In the early spring of 1836, Grant and [[Frank W. Johnson]] continued their quest towards Matamoros. As co-commanders of the [[Matamoros Expedition]] with about 70 to 100 men, they went as far as San Patricio to gather horses for their expedition.Santos (1968), p. 65. Grant was informed that Mexican Captain Nicolás Rodríguez and a small company formerly from Fort Lipantitlán was in the area. Grant confronted and overtook them, confiscated their horses and took the men as prisoners to San Patricio. Within a few days the prisoners had escaped, alerting Mexican forces. Splitting into smaller groups, the Texians searched for mounts and supplies, proceeding all the way to [[Raymondville, Texas|Santa Rosa Ranch]]. Grant and a group of fifteen [[Texians]] while foraging, were attacked by members of General [[José de Urrea]]'s cavalry. Grant was killed in the [[battle of Agua Dulce]] at 10:30 a.m. on March 2, 1836.Hardin (1994), p. 111. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Barr|first=Alwyn|authorlink=Alwyn Barr|title=Texans in Revolt: the Battle for San Antonio, 1835|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, TX|year=1990|isbn=0-292-77042-1}} *{{cite book|last=Hardin|first=Stephen L.|authorlink=Stephen L. Hardin|year=1994|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, TX|title=Texian Iliad – A Military History of the Texas Revolution|isbn=0-292-73086-1}} *{{cite book|last=Henson|first=Margaret Swett|title=Juan Davis Bradburn: A Reappraisal of the Mexican Commander of Anahuac|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|location=College Station, TX|year=1982|isbn=978-0-89096-135-3}} *{{cite book|last=Reid|first=Stuart|title=The Secret War for Texas|series=Elma Dill Russell Spencer Series in the West and Southwest|number=28|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|location=College Station, Texas|year=2007|isbn=978-1-58544-565-3}} *{{cite book|last=Santos|first=Richard G.|title=Santa Anna's campaign against Texas, 1835-1836;: Featuring the field commands issued to Major General Vicente Filisola|publisher=Texian Press|year=1968|edition=First|asin=B0006BV0Y8}} *{{cite book|last=Todish|first=Timothy J.|last2=Todish|first2=Terry|last3=Spring|first3=Ted|title=Alamo Sourcebook, 1836: A Comprehensive Guide to the Battle of the Alamo and the Texas Revolution|publisher=Eakin Press|year=1998|location=Austin, TX|isbn=978-1-57168-152-2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grant, James}} [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:1793 births]] [[Category:Scottish emigrants to Mexico]] [[Category:1836 deaths]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Jean Le Bitoux | image = Yves Navarre et Jean Le Bitoux par Claude Truong-Ngoc, 1981.png | image_size = | caption = Jean Le Bitoux (right) with [[Yves Navarre]], 1981 | birth_name = | birth_date = 16 August 1948 | birth_place = [[Bordeaux]], France | death_date = 21 April 2010 | death_place = [[Paris]], France | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Journalist | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Jean Le Bitoux''' (16 August 1948 - 21 April 2010) was a French journalist and gay activist. He was the founder of ''[[Gai pied]]'', the first mainstream gay magazine in France. He was a campaigner for Holocaust remembrance of homosexual victims. He was the author of several books about homosexuality.
==Early life== Jean Le Bitoux was born on 16 August 1948 in [[Bordeaux]], France.<ref name="lemondeobit">{{cite news|last1=Chemin|first1=Anne|title=Jean Le Bitoux|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/disparitions/article/2010/04/27/jean-le-bitoux_1343324_3382.html|accessdate=11 August 2016|work=Le Monde|date=27 April 2010}}</ref><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux">{{cite journal|last1=Halperin|first1=David M.|title=Michel Foucault, Jean Le Bitoux, and the Gay Science Lost and Found: An Introduction|journal=Critical Inquiry|date=Spring 2011|volume=37|issue=3|pages=371–380|doi=10.1086/659349|jstor=10.1086/659349|registration=yes}}</ref> His father was an admiral.<ref name="martelthepink">{{cite book|last1=Martel|first1=Frédéric|title=The Pink and the Black: Homosexuals in France since 1968|date=1999|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=Stanford, California|isbn=9780804732734|oclc=42643256|pages=107–108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nnz57zheGWcC&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=jean+le+bitoux&source=bl&ots=9BxqECZD31&sig=1oRSSpvzLJjLc5k8c6n5o_w_VS4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwja-Or07LnOAhUIDcAKHXv7B7M4FBDoAQgrMAM#v=onepage&q=jean%20le%20bitoux&f=false}}</ref>
==Career== Le Bitoux worked as a substitute music teacher.<ref name="martelthepink"/>
Le Bitoux founded the Front homosexuel d'action révolutionnaire (FHAR) in [[Nice]] in the 1970s.<ref name="lemondeobit"/><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/> By 1978, he ran for the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] as a "homosexual candidate" alongside [[Guy Hocquenghem]]; they lost the election.<ref name="lemondeobit"/><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/>
In 1979, Le Bitoux founded ''[[Gai pied]]'', the first long-running commercially published gay magazine in France;<ref name="lemondeobit"/><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/> its name was coined by philosopher [[Michel Foucault]].<ref name="martelthepink"/> However, Le Bitoux stepped down in 1983 due to the magazine's increasingly consumerist orientation.<ref name="libfavereau">{{cite news|last1=Favereau|first1=Eric|title="Jean Le Bitoux, militant de la mémoire gay"|url=http://www.liberation.fr/societe/2010/04/30/jean-le-bitoux-militant-de-la-memoire-gay_623516|accessdate=11 August 2016|work=[[Libération]]|date=30 April 2010}}</ref>
Le Bitoux joined [[AIDES]], an HIV/AIDS awareness non-profit organization, in 1985.<ref name="libfavereau"/><ref name="broquaagir">{{cite book|last1=Broqua|first1=Christophe|title=Agir pour ne pas mourir ! Act up, les homosexuels et le sida|date=2005|publisher=Les Presses de Sciences Po|location=Paris|isbn=9782724609813|oclc=469793514|pages=115–161|url=http://www.cairn.info/article.php?ID_ARTICLE=SCPO_BROQU_2005_01_0115&DocId=386304&hits=19858+19857+19856+19242+19241+19240+17480+17479+17478+|via=[[Cairn.info]]|registration=yes}}</ref> He co-wrote many HIV prevention documents.<ref name="libfavereau"/> He was the editor-in-chief of the ''Journal du Sida'', a publication about HIV/AIDS.<ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/>
In 1989, Le Bitoux founded the Mémorial de la Déportation Homosexuelle, a nonprofit organization for the remembrance of homosexuals victims of Nazi Germany9.<ref name="lemondeobit"/><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/> Initially, the organization was met with homophobia from some Holocaust survivors, who wrongly feared they were being smeared.<ref name="ilparaitcelse">{{cite journal|last1=Celse|first1=Michel|title=Il paraît que le mouvement gai a 100 ans...|journal=Vacarme|date=1997|volume=3|issue=3|pages=44–46|doi=10.3917/vaca.003.0044|url=http://www.cairn.info/article.php?ID_ARTICLE=VACA_003_0044&DocId=9565&hits=3937+3936+3935+3857+3856+3855+3662+3661+3660+|accessdate=14 August 2016|via=[[Cairn.info]]|registration=yes|quote=Cette revendication se heurte régulièrement à des refus violemment homophobes de la part de différentes associations d’anciens déportés, qui y voient une entreprise visant à salir leur mémoire.}}</ref> In 1994, Le Bitoux co-authored the memoir of [[Pierre Seel]], a French homosexual who was deported by the Nazis for being gay.<ref name="lemondeobit"/><ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/>
By the 1990s, Le Bitoux argued that anti-LGBT legislations in France harked back to laws devised by [[François Darlan]] of the Vichy government to end same-sex prostitution in 1942, not Nazi Germany.<ref name="ordremoral143">{{cite book|last1=Boninchi|first1=Marc|title=Vichy et l'ordre moral|url=http://www.cairn.info/vichy-et-l-ordre-moral--9782130553397-page-143.htm|date=2005|publisher=PUF|location=Paris|isbn=9782130553397|oclc=420826274|pages=143–193|via=[[Cairn.info]]|registration=yes}}</ref> However, Marc Boninchi, a Law professor at the [[University of Lyon]], has argued that the first instance of legal discrimination dates back to prosecutor [[Charles Dubost]]'s 1941 recommendations.<ref name="ordremoral143"/> Meanwhile, Le Bitoux's 2002 ''Les oubliés de la mémoire'' led President [[Jacques Chirac]] to acknowledge the homosexual victims of World War II.<ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/>
Le Bitoux was a co-founder of the [[Centre LGBT Paris-Île-de-France]] in 1991.<ref name="whoswho241">{{cite book|last1=Aldrich|first1=Robert|last2=Wotherspoon|first2=Garry|title=Who's Who in Gay and Lesbian History|date=2001|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=9780415159821|oclc=46843939|page=241}}</ref>
==Personal life== Le Bitoux was openly gay, and was rejected by his family for being gay.<ref name="lemondeobit"/> Drawn to [[Maoism]] in his early twenties, he also left due to homophobia.<ref name="lemondeobit"/> He contracted HIV/AIDS in the early 1980s.<ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/><ref name="libfavereau"/>
==Death== Le Bitoux died on 21 April 2010 in Paris, France.<ref name="lemondeobit"/> A memorial service conducted by [[Patrick Bloche]] was held in his honor at the city hall of the [[11th arrondissement of Paris]], with a performance by the [[Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence]].<ref name="halperinjeanlebitoux"/> He was buried at the [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]].<ref name="libfavereau"/>
==Works== * {{cite book|last1=Le Bitoux|first1=Jean|last2=Seel|first2=Pierre|title=Moi, Pierre Seel, déporté homosexuel|date=1994|publisher=Calmann-Lévy|location=Paris|isbn=9782702122778|oclc=30927212}} * {{cite book|last1=Le Bitoux|first1=Jean|title=Les oubliés de la mémoire|date=2002|publisher=Hachette littératures|location=Paris|isbn=9782012356252|oclc=50541993}} * {{cite book|last1=Chevaux|first1=Hervé|last2=Le Bitoux|first2=Jean|last3=Proth|first3=Bruno|title=Citoyen de seconde zone : trente ans de lutte pour la reconnaissance de l'homosexualité en France (1971-2002)|date=2003|publisher=Hachette Littératures|location=Paris|isbn=9782012355682|oclc=402382714}} * {{cite book|last1=Le Bitoux|first1=Jean|title=Entretiens sur la question gay|date=2005|publisher=H & O|location=Béziers|isbn=9782845470989|oclc=60596632}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{commons category-inline|Jean Le Bitoux}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Le Bitoux, Jean}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at Père Lachaise Cemetery]] [[Category:French journalists]] [[Category:French non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:LGBT writers from France]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from France]] [[Category:People from Bordeaux]] [[Category:People with HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:French-language LGBT writers]]

{{Infobox person | name = Joanna Troutman | image = Joanna Troutman Texas Capitol.jpg | caption = Joanna Troutman portrait in [[Texas State Capitol]] | imagesize = 260px | birth_date = {{birth-date|19 February 1818}} | birth_place = [[Baldwin County, Georgia]] | death_date = {{death-date and age|23 July 1879|19 February 1818}} | death_place = [[Knoxville, Georgia]] | birth_name = Joanna Troutman | spouse = Solomon L. Pope
W. G. Vinson | occupation = Flag maker | nationality = American }} [[File:Flag of Georgia Battalion.svg|thumb|right|280px|This flag designed by Joanna Troutman known as the "Troutman Flag" was used by the Georgia Battalion under the command of [[William Ward (Texas)|William Ward]] which marched from [[Macon, Georgia]] to participate in the fight against Mexico and were killed in the [[Battle of the Alamo]] in 1836]] '''Joanna Troutman''' also '''Johanna Troutman''' (19 February 1818 – 23 July 1879) sewed a flag for a battalion of Georgia volunteers who were leaving to fight in the [[Texas Revolution]], which became known as the [[Troutman flag]], consisting of a five-pointed blue star and the words "Liberty or Death" on a white silk field. On the reverse side was the Latin phrase UBI LIBERTAS HABITAT, IBI NOSTRA PATRIA EST which means "Where liberty dwells, there is our fatherland". On 8 January 1836 the flag was raised at [[Velasco, Texas|Velasco]] which is now part of modern [[Freeport, Texas]]. The original flag was badly damaged by accident and only shreds flew in battle.tshaonline.org, ''Troutman, Joanna'' ==Background== The Georgians, who were led by [[William Ward (Texas)|William Ward]], suffered a harsh fate. Though they escaped the [[Battle of Coleto]] and the capitulation of [[James W. Fannin]]'s command, they were pursued by [[José de Urrea]]'s cavalry. Out of ammunition, they finally surrendered and were marched back to Goliad to join the rest of Fannin's captured troops. On 27 March 1836 they were nearly all executed in the [[Goliad massacre]].tshaonline.org, ''Ward, William'' ==Life== Born in [[Baldwin County, Georgia]] on 19 February 1818, Troutman was the daughter of Hiram Bainbridge Troutman. In 1839 she married Solomom L. Pope and moved to a plantation in [[Knoxville, Georgia]] called Elmwood. The couple had four sons. Her husband died in 1872 and in 1875 she wed W. G. Vinson, who served in the Georgia state legislature. She died on 23 July 1879 at Elmwood and was buried next to her first husband. At the request of Texas governor [[Oscar Branch Colquitt]] her remains were transferred to the [[Texas State Cemetery]] in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in 1913. Her portrait hangs in one of the legislative chambers of the Texas Capitol. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ftr13 Texas State Historical Association tshaonline.org ''Troutman, Joanna''] *[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fwa53 Texas State Historical Association tshaonline.org ''Ward, William''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Troutman, Joanna}} [[Category:People from Baldwin County, Georgia]] [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:Burials at Texas State Cemetery]] [[Category:1818 births]] [[Category:1879 deaths]] [[Category:People from Crawford County, Georgia]] [[Category:People from Freeport, Texas]]

revision.comment: minor fixes, replaced: [[teacher]] → teacher, volume=XXII, | → volume=XXII | (6) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{About|the Australian convict and teacher|the New Zealand teacher and education inspector|John Hislop (teacher)}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2016}} '''James John Henry Hislop''' (1825 – 23 October 1909) was a [[Convict era of Western Australia|convict]] [[penal transportation|transported]] to [[Western Australia]]. After the expiry of his sentence, he became the first ex-convict in Western Australia to be appointed a teacher.
==Life== John Hislop was a [[clerk (position)|clerk]] in the [[British Army]] before being sentenced to seven years transportation for an unknown crime. He arrived in Western Australia on board the ''Pyrenees'' in June 1851 and received his [[Ticket of leave#Australian convicts|ticket of leave]] on arrival in the colony. In October 1853 he married Bridget Mulqueen, with whom he would have twelve children.
Hislop was officially appointed the government schoolteacher at [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]] in 1853, but it is said that he was already conducting the school before then. He ran the school for nine years, during which time he taught [[John Forrest|John]] and [[Alexander Forrest]]. He was considered a poor teacher by the Board of Education, which wrote that the "school had not progressed as satisfactorily as the Board would wish".
In 1862, Hislop was charged with obtaining money by false pretences.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69135986 |title=Local and Domestic Intelligence. |newspaper=[[The Inquirer and Commercial News]] |volume=XXII |issue=1,118 |location=Western Australia |date=2 July 1862 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He was acquitted, but still dismissed from his teaching post for "improper conduct". He then became the proprietor of the Wellington Hotel,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article214600444 |title=BUNBURY JOTTINGS. |newspaper=[[Victorian Express]] |volume=IX |issue=6 |location=Western Australia |date=16 October 1886 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and later a [[councillor]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164853334 |title=Bunbury Municipal Election. |newspaper=[[Southern Times]] |volume=1 |issue=14 |location=Western Australia |date=27 November 1888 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
He died in Bunbury on 23 October 1909.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article158880885 |title=OBITUARY. |newspaper=[[Southern Times]] |volume=22 |issue=25 |location=Western Australia |date=23 October 1909 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=5 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article87256638 |title=Obituary. |newspaper=[[Bunbury Herald]] |volume=XIX |issue=3223 |location=Western Australia |date=28 October 1909 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article211593019 |title=AN OLD SCHOOLMASTER |newspaper=[[The Sun (Kalgoorlie)|The Sun]] |issue=568 |location=Kalgoorlie |date=24 October 1909 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article203497753 |title=OLD IDENTITY |newspaper=[[The Evening Star]] |volume=12 |issue=3574 |location=Western Australia |date=26 October 1909 |accessdate=21 August 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ex-convict school teachers in Western Australia]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{cite book|editor=Erickson, Rica (ed)|year=1983|title=The Brand on His Coat|author=[[Rica Erickson|Erickson, Rica]]|chapter=Schoolmasters|location=Nedlands, Western Australia | publisher=University of Western Australia Press|isbn=0-85564-223-8}}
<!-- Bunbury town council -->

{{confusing|date=December 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2015}} '''Josef Erwin Bachmann''' (12 October 1944 [[Reichenbach im Vogtland]], [[Saxony]] – 24 February 1970) became widely known in [[Germany]] for his [[assassination]] attempt on the [[Marxist]] activist [[Rudi Dutschke]], firing three bullets at him, on 11 April 1968. He was convicted of the attack and sentenced to a seven-year prison sentence. While in prison in 1970, Bachmann committed suicide.
==Attack== Bachmann approached Dutschke, whom he had never met, in the street, having found out his address from the ''Einwohnermeldeamt'', the registration office. Asking him if he was really Rudi Dutschke, he took out a gun and shot him in the head. Later on he told the judge that he had done it out of hate, calling Dutschke a "dirty [[communist]] pig". After the shooting, Bachmann fled to a cellar where he took an overdose of sleeping pills but still continued firing his gun at police officers trying to approach him. He was taken to a hospital to deal with the effects of his overdose.
Dutschke survived the assassination attempt but suffered brain damage and was forced to learn to speak again. He was left with severe health problems which in 1979 led to his death in [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]].
After Bachmann's conviction, he and Dutschke corresponded by letter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lieber Josef Bachmann: Diese Briefe schrieb Dutschke an seinen Attentäter|url=http://www.bild.de/politik/2010/an-attentaeter-josef-bachmann-12348078.bild.html|website=Der Bild|date=27 April 2010|accessdate=2017-02-20}}</ref> Bachmann committed suicide on the night of 23-24 February 1970 by suffocating himself with a plastic bag over his head.
==In media== Bachmann was portrayed by [[Tom Schilling]] in the 2008 film ''[[Der Baader Meinhof Komplex]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bachmann, Josef}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:1970 deaths]] [[Category:People from Reichenbach im Vogtland]] [[Category:German criminals]] [[Category:1968 in Germany]] [[Category:Criminals who committed suicide]] [[Category:German prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Germany]] [[Category:German anti-communists]]
{{Germany-bio-stub}} {{Crime-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: P Aculeius moved page [[Iulius Iullus]] to [[Julius Iulus]]: Regularizing orthography; other articles about gens Julia use the English spelling, and Iulus with one 'l'.
revision.text:
'''Julius Iullus''' was the name of a branch of the ''[[Julia (gens)|gens Julia]]'' in [[ancient Rome]]. The Iulus or Iullus branch was older than the more famous branch of [[Julii Caesares]], who may have been an offshoot.<ref>[[Ernst Badian]], "From the Iulii to Caesar," in ''A Companion to Julius Caesar'' (Blackwell, 2009), pp. 13–14.</ref> Iulii Iulli include:
*'''Lucius Julius Iulus''' was [[Magister Equitum]] in 430 BC,<ref>[[Livy]] 4.26.11 and 27.1; [[Diodorus Siculus]] 12.64.1–3; [[T.R.S. Broughton]], ''The Magistrates of the Roman Republic'' (American Philological Association, 1951, 1986), vol. 1, p. 63.</ref> and [[Roman consul|consul]] in 430.<ref>Livy 4.30.1; Diodorus 12.72.1; Broughton, ''MRR<sup>1</sup>'', p. 64.</ref> [[Cicero]] has the ''praenomen'' as Gaius.<ref>Cicero, ''[[De re publica]]'' 2.60; Broughton, ''MRR<sup>1</sup>'', p. 64.</ref> He and his consular colleague Papirius Crassus granted an eight-year truce to the [[Aequi]],<ref>Livy 4.30.1–2; Broughton, ''MRR<sup>1</sup>'', p. 64.</ref> and passed legislation that allowed fines to be paid in cash ''(pecunia)'' instead of livestock ''(pecudes)''.<ref>Cicero, ''De re publica'' 2.60; Livy 4.30.3; Broughton, ''MRR<sup>1</sup>'', p. 64.</ref> * several other '''Lucius Julius Iulus''', who were [[consular tribune]]s from 403 BC to 379 BC. * several men named '''[[Gaius Julius Iulus]]'''. * '''Sextus Julius Iulus''', [[consular tribune]] in 424 BC.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Julii| ]] [[Category:Ancient Roman prosopographical lists]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people in ancient Rome]]

'''Klaus Riedel''' (August 2, 1907 – August 4, 1944) was a German [[rocket]] pioneer. He was involved in many early liquid-fuelled rocket experiments, and eventually worked on the [[V-2]] missile programme at [[Peenemünde Army Research Center]].
==History== Riedel was born in [[Wilhelmshaven]], the son of a naval officer. His mother died when he was twelve years old, and his father two years later. The orphaned Riedel was raised by his grandmother in [[Bernstadt auf dem Eigen|Bernstadt]]. He went on to study as a machinist at the [[Technical University of Berlin]] and to work at [[Löwe Automobil|Löwe]]. While in Berlin, he attended a public lecture on rocketry by [[Rudolf Nebel]] on behalf of Germany's amateur rocket group, the ''[[Verein für Raumschiffahrt]]'' (VfR - "Spaceflight Society") and joined the group straight away, becoming very active in its efforts to build a working rocket that resulted in the [[Mirak (rocket)|Mirak]] and [[Repulsor rocket]]s, providing his family's farm as a testing ground.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/mirak.htm | title = Mirak | publisher = [[Encyclopedia Astronautica]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100107193935/http://astronautix.com/lvs/mirak.htm | archivedate = 2010-01-07 | df = }}</ref>
After the VfR disbanded in 1933, Riedel was invited by [[Wernher von Braun]] to join him in the army's rocket programme. He accepted, and worked from Peenemünde when the team moved there. Riedel's position was "Head of the Test Laboratory" and his work seems to have been mostly concerned with developing the mobile support equipment for the V-2.
He was killed in a car accident two days after his thirty-seventh birthday.
There is a memorial and small museum dedicated to him in Bernstadt and in 1970 a crater on the moon was named after him.
==References== <references/>
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Riedel, Klaus}} [[Category:German rocket scientists]] [[Category:German engineers]] [[Category:V-weapons people]] [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Early spaceflight scientists]] [[Category:People from Wilhelmshaven]] [[Category:People from the Province of Hanover]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in Germany]] [[Category:Technical University of Berlin alumni]] [[Category:Peenemünde Army Research Center and Airfield]] [[Category:20th-century engineers]] [[Category:20th-century German scientists]]

revision.comment: Well it said she was the king it only makes sense that her Wikipedia page has king by her name
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = King Kubaba | children = [[Puzur-Suen]] | title = Queen of Sumer | image = Museum of Anatolian Civilizations086.jpg | caption = Kubaba holding a [[Opium|poppy capsule]] (possibly a pomegranate) and a [[Tympanum (hand drum)|tympanum]] (or perhaps a mirror)
Museum of Anatolian Civilizations, Ankara, Turkey | image size = 180px | relatives = [[Ur-Zababa]] (grandson) }} '''Kubaba''' (in the ''Weidner'' or ''[[Esagila]] Chronicle'';[http://www.livius.org/cg-cm/chronicles/abc19/weidner.html The Weidner Chronicle (ABC 19) or Esagila Chronicle]. [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]]: '''Kug-Bau''') is the [[Queen regnant|only queen]] on the ''[[Sumerian King List]]'', which states she reigned for 100 years – roughly in the Early Dynastic III period (ca. 2500-2330 BC) of [[History of Sumer|Sumerian history]]. In later times, she was worshipped as a goddess. ==Queen== Kubaba is one of very few women to have ever ruled in their own right in Iraqi history. Most versions of the king list place her alone in her own dynasty, the 3rd Dynasty of [[Kish (Sumer)|Kish]], following the defeat of Sharrumiter of [[Mari, Syria|Mari]], but other versions combine her with the 4th dynasty, that followed the primacy of the king of [[Akshak]]. Before becoming monarch, the king list says she was an [[Alewife (trade)|alewife]]. The ''Weidner Chronicle'' is a propagandistic letter, attempting to date the shrine of [[Marduk]] at [[Babylon]] to an early period, and purporting to show that each of the kings who had neglected its proper rites had lost the primacy of Sumer. It contains a brief account of rise of "the house of Kubaba" occurring in the reign of [[Puzur-Nirah]] of Akshak:
"In the reign of Puzur-Nirah, king of Akšak, the freshwater fishermen of [[Esagila]] were catching fish for the meal of the great lord Marduk; the officers of the king took away the fish. The fisherman was fishing when 7 (or 8) days had passed [...] in the house of Kubaba, the tavern-keeper [...] they brought to Esagila. At that time BROKEN[4] anew for Esagila [...] Kubaba gave bread to the fisherman and gave water, she made him offer the fish to Esagila. Marduk, the king, the prince of the Apsû, favored her and said: "Let it be so!" He entrusted to Kubaba, the tavern-keeper, sovereignty over the whole world."
Her son [[Puzur-Suen]] and grandson [[Ur-Zababa]] followed her on the throne in Sumer as the fourth Kish dynasty on the king list, in some copies as her direct successors, in others with the Akshak dynasty intervening. Ur-Zababa is also known as the king said to be reigning in Sumer during the youth of [[Sargon the Great]] of [[Akkadian Empire|Akkad]], who militarily brought much of the Near East under his regime shortly afterward. == Goddess == Shrines in honour of Kubaba spread throughout [[Mesopotamia]].The Weidner "Chronicle" mentioning Kubaba from Grayson, A.K. (1975) "Assyrian and Babylonian Chronicles"Munn, Mark (2004). "Kybele as Kubaba in a Lydo-Phrygian Context": Emory University cross-cultural conference "Hittites, Greeks and Their Neighbors in Central Anatolia" (Abstracts) In the [[Hurrians|Hurrian]] area, she may be identified with Kebat, or [[Hebat|Hepat]], one title of the Hurrian Mother goddess [[Hannahannah]] (from Hurrian ''hannah'', "mother"). [[Abdi-Heba]] was the palace mayor, ruling [[Jerusalem]] at the time of the [[Amarna letters]] (1350 BC). Kubaba became the tutelary goddess who protected the ancient city of [[Carchemish]] on the upper [[Euphrates]], in the late Hurrian/early [[Hittites|Hittite]] period.F. Graf, ''Nordionische Kulte'' (Rome) 1985:111, noted by Jan N. Bremmer, "Attis: A Greek God in Anatolian Pessinous and Catullan Rome" ''Mnemosyne'', Fourth Series, '''57'''.5 (2004:534-573) p. 539. Relief carvings, now at the [[Museum of Anatolian Civilizations]] (Anadolu Medeniyetleri Müzesi), [[Ankara]], show her seated, wearing a cylindrical headdress like the ''polos'' and holding probably a [[tympanum (hand drum)]] or possibly a mirror in one hand and a [[Opium|poppy capsule]] (or perhaps [[pomegranate]]) in the other. She plays a role in [[Luwian language|Luwian]] texts and a minor role in Hittite texts, mainly in Hurrian rituals. According to Emanuel Laroche, Maarten J. Vermaseren, and Mark Munn, her cult later spread and her name was adapted for the main goddess of the Hittite successor kingdoms in [[Anatolia]].Laroche 1960; Vermaseren 1977; Munn, 2004< This deity later developed into the [[Phrygia]]n [[Cybele|''matar kubileya'']] ("mother Cybele"),Munn, 2004 who was depicted in [[petroglyph]]s and mentioned in accompanying inscriptions.[[C.H.E. Haspels]], ''The Highlands of Phrygia'' 1971, I 293 no 13, noted in Walter Burkert, ''Greek Religion'', 1985, III.3.5 notes 17 and 18. The Phrygian goddess otherwise bears little resemblance to Kubaba, who – according to Herodotus – was a sovereign deity at [[Sardis]].[[Herodotus]] 5.102.1, noted by Munn 2004 Her [[Lydia]]n name was '''Kuvav''' or '''Kufav''' which [[Ionia|Ionian Greeks]] initially transcribed '''Kybêbê''', rather than ''Kybele''; Jan Bremmer notes in this context the 7th century [[Semonides of Amorgos]], who calls one of her Hellene followers a ''kybêbos''.Bremmer 2004:539 notes Semonides Fr 39 (West). Bremmer observes that in the following century she was further Hellenized by [[Hipponax]], as "Kybêbê, daughter of [[Zeus]]".Bremmer 2004:539 notes Hipponax Fr 125 Degani equivalent to Fr 127 West. {{Portal|Ancient Near East}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[http://www.livius.org/cg-cm/chronicles/abc19/weidner.html "The Weidner 'Chronicle' mentioning Kubaba"]. From Grayson, A. K. (1975). ''Assyrian and Babylonian Chronicles''. *Munn, Mark (2004). [https://web.archive.org/web/20100516110343/http://www.mesas.emory.edu/anatconf/abstracts.htm "Kybele as Kubaba in a Lydo-Phrygian Context"]: Emory University cross-cultural conference "Hittites, Greeks and Their Neighbors in Central Anatolia" (Abstracts) *Laroche Emmanuel, "Kubaba déesse anatolienne, et le problème des origines de Cybèle", Eléments orientaux dans la religion grecque ancienne, Paris 1960, p. 113-128. *Vermaseren, Maarten J., ''Cybele and Attis; the Myth and the Cult,'' A.M.H. Lemmers, Trans., Thames and Hudson, London. (1970) ==Outside links== [http://sumerianshakespeare.com/748301/769001.html Queen Ku-Baba, the first female monarch in history, and the destruction of her legacy by Sargon.] {{S-start}} {{Succession box |before=[[En-shag-kush-ana]] of [[Uruk]] |title=[[Sumerian king list|Queen of Sumer]] |years=ca. 25th century BC |after=King of [[Akshak]] }} {{Succession box |before=(unknown) |title=[[Ruler (potentate)|Ruler]] of [[Kish (Sumer)|Kish]] |years=ca. 25th century BC |after=(unknown) }} {{s-end}} {{Notable Rulers of Sumer}} [[Category:25th-century BC women rulers]] [[Category:Sumerian rulers]] [[Category:Ancient queens regnant]] [[Category:Mesopotamian goddesses]] [[Category:Tutelary deities]] [[Category:Deified people]] [[Category:Ancient Mesopotamian women]]

page.title: List of Harper's Bazaar UK cover models

revision.text:
This article is a catalog of actresses and models who have appeared on the cover of '''''Harper's Bazaar UK''''', the British edition of [[Harper's Bazaar]] magazine, starting in 2007. ==2007== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="font-size:95%; width:100%;" |- ! style="text-align:center;"| Issue

Athletics|Kansas City Athletics]], [[Philadelphia Phillies]], [[Cleveland Indians]], and [[St. Louis Cardinals]] |- --> |}
*[[Tommy Lasorda]], at {{age|1927|9|22}}, is the oldest living member of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|National Baseball Hall of Fame]]. *[[Alex Grammas]], at {{age|1926|4|3}}, is the oldest living former manager, having managed the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] (1969) and the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] (1976–1977). *[[Eddie Robinson (baseball)|Eddie Robinson]], at {{age|1920|12|15}}, is the oldest living former major league [[coach (baseball)|coach]] – having coached with the [[Baltimore Orioles]] (1958–60). *[[Eddie Basinski]], at {{age|1922|11|4}}, is the last living major leaguer mentioned in the [[Dave Frishberg]] song [[Van Lingle Mungo (song)|Van Lingle Mungo]]. *[[Don Newcombe]], at {{age|1926|6|14}}, is the oldest living major leaguer mentioned in the [[Terry Cashman]] song [[Talkin' Baseball]]. *[[Bill Terry]] was the last living person mentioned in Ogden Nash's poem [[Line-Up for Yesterday]]. He died in 1989, aged {{Age in years and days|1898|10|30|1989|1|9}}. *[[Bobby Doerr]], a second baseman for the [[Boston Red Sox]], was the longest-lived member of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]] when he died in 2017 at the age of 99. *[[Red Hoff]], a pitcher for the [[New York Yankees]] and [[St. Louis Browns]], was the longest-lived major leaguer – he died in 1998, aged {{Age in years and days|1891|5|8|1998|9|17}}. *[[Silas Simmons]], who played in the Negro leagues, is believed to have been the longest-lived professional baseball player in history – his year of birth is disputed, but he was at least 109 and possibly 111 at the time of his death in 2006.
==See also== *[[List of oldest Major League Baseball players]] *[[List of centenarians (Major League Baseball players)]]
==Sources== *[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/ Baseball Almanac] *[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/baseballlibrary/ballplayers/ Baseball Library] *[http://www.thebaseballpage.com/ The Baseball Page] *[https://www.baseball-reference.com/ Baseball Reference] *[http://www.wa-wd.com/l_majlea.asp Oldest Living Major League Baseball Players] *[http://www.whosaliveandwhosdead.com/ Who's Alive and Who's Dead]
[[Category:Lists of Major League Baseball players|Oldest living]] [[Category:Lists of oldest people|MLB players]]

page.title: List of people barred or excluded from the United States

revision.text:
The following is a list of notable people who are, have been or were barred from entering the United States. The [[Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] (ICE) of the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) handles deportation in the United States, often in conjunction with advice from the [[U.S. State Department|U.S. Department of State]].{{Cite book|contribution=Deportation|title=The Columbia Electronic Encyclopedia, 6th ed.|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2007|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/history/A0815199.html|accessdate=16 November 2008}} Such bans are often temporary, depending on the circumstances of each case, however, anyone previously deported or denaturalized is automatically barred from re-entering the United States without a waiver issued by the U.S. Department of State. ==List== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=260|Individual ! width=200|Nationality ! width=350 class="unsortable"|Reasons for ban |- |[[Hamid Aboutalebi]] |{{flagcountry|IRN}} |Iranian diplomat and envoy to the [[United Nations]] denied a visa in April 2014 to enter the United States because of his role as a translator for the militants who stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and [[Iran hostage crisis|held 52 American citizens hostage for 444 days]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/12/world/middleeast/white-house-says-no-visa-for-irans-un-envoy.html?ref=middleeast Iranian diplomat Hamid Aboutalebi denied visa], nytimes.com, 12 April 2014; accessed 14 April 2014. |- |[[Gerry Adams]] |{{flagcountry|IRL}} |[[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]], later President of [[Sinn Féin]], was denied a visa on several occasions[http://articles.philly.com/1987-10-23/news/26214040_1_gerry-adams-sinn-fein-northern-ireland "Gerry Adams To Visit? Ruling Could Open Visa Gate To Sinn Feiner"], philly.com, 23 October 1987; accessed 2 June 2014 on the grounds that he refused to renounce violence.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/adams-is-allowed-48hour-us-visa-clinton-agrees-visit-despite-dispute-1410627.html "Adams is allowed 48-hour US visa: Clinton agrees visit despite dispute"], ''The Independent'', 31 January 1994 Adams was granted a limited (48-hour) visa in January 1994, and would visit the U.S. on several further occasions. In 2006, however, Adams was denied a fundraising visa by the US government.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7453972.stm "Adams visit cools US/UK relations"], BBC.co.uk, 13 June 2008; accessed 2 June 2014. |- |[[Lily Allen]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |British singer, banned in 2007 from the U.S. after her U.S. work visa was revoked following her arrest earlier the same year on charges of assaulting a photographer in [[London]].[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/lily-allens-aussie-blues/story-e6frewz0-1111114135716 "Lily Allen banned from U.S. after arrest for hitting a paparazzo in 2007"], ''The Daily Telegraph''; accessed 3 January 2016. She regained a US work visa in October, 2008.[https://people.com/celebrity/lily-allen-granted-u-s-visa/ "Lily Allen Granted U.S. Visa"], ''People Magazine''; accessed 08 August 2018. |- |[[Luke Angel]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |A British teen who sent a curse-laden e-mail message to the White House directed at President [[Barack Obama]] and was subsequently banned for life from entering the United States. [[Bedfordshire Police]] visited Angel at his home in [[Silsoe]], [[Bedfordshire]], and Angel, who was 17 at the time of the incident, admitted to sending the e-mail, although he claimed he could not remember what he wrote. No criminal action against Angel was taken in the UK.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/8003542/British-teenager-banned-from-US-over-drunken-email-to-Barack-Obama.html "Drunk e-mailing the President of the United States, however, can get you banned from the country - permanently"], ''New York Daily News'', 13 September 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-11296303|title=Obama e-mail teenager gets US ban|date=14 September 2010|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} |- |[[Kurt Blome]] |{{flagicon|GER}}/{{flagcountry|GER|Nazi}} |Blome, a German microbiologist and Nazi scientist, was acquitted at Nuremberg. In 1951, he was hired by the U.S. Army [[Chemical Corps]] under Project 63, one of the successors to [[Operation Paperclip]], to work on [[chemical warfare]]. His file neglected to mention [[Doctors' Trial|Nuremberg]]. Denied a visa by the U.S. Consul in Frankfurt, he was employed at European Command Intelligence Center at Oberursel, West Germany.{{cite book|author1=[[George J. Annas]]|author2=[[Michael A. Grodin]]|title=The Nazi doctors and the Nuremberg Code: Human Rights in Human Experimentation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4P04DuPIfAYC|date=1 August 1995|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-510106-5}} Blome died in 1969. |- |[[Boy George]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} | British singer and fashion designer. Boy George (real name George O'Dowd) was denied a visa in 2008 by US immigration officials while facing trial in the UK in November of that year. The singer had been ordered to clean the streets of New York as community service in 2006 after pleading guilty to falsely reporting a burglary. An official statement from his management said: ''"At the moment, Boy George cannot come to the United States of America because he has been refused permission to enter by the USA Administration. This is not in respect of anything he has done in the past but because he is facing a trial in November in London for something that happened in April last year."''Khan, Urmee (24 June 2008) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/2186572/Boy-George-banned-from-singing-in-the-US.html Boy George banned from U.S.], ''The Telegraph'' On 5 December 2008, O'Dowd was convicted in [[Snaresbrook]] Crown Court, London, of the assault and [[false imprisonment]] of a paid sex partner (male escort) in the singer's apartment on their first encounter.Angela Balakrishna [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/05/2 "Boy George guilty of falsely imprisoning male escort"], ''The Guardian'', 5 December 2008. On 16 January 2009, O'Dowd was sentenced to 15 months in prison for these offences.{{Cite news|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/7832565.stm|title=Boy George jailed for 15 months|date=16 January 2008|accessdate=10 April 2014}} For this O'Dowd was again denied entry to the United States.[http://blogs.ilw.com/entry.php?3356-BOY-GEORGE-DENIED-ENTRY-TO-US "Boy George Denied Entry to US"], ilw.com; accessed 10 April 2014. The ban was lifted in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://emptylighthouse.com/boy-georges-us-ban-lifted-culture-club-performs-view-1691129407|title=Boy George's US Ban Lifted; Culture Club Performs on 'The View'|first=Helen|last=Chan|date=6 November 2014|publisher=}} |- |[[Hortensia Bussi|Hortensia Bussi de Allende]] |{{flagcountry|CHI}} |Widow of [[Chile]]an President [[Salvador Allende]], who was overthrown, was barred from entering the United States when she attempted to do so in 1983.[https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/world/mrs-allende-is-barred-from-entering-the-us.html ''New York Times'' report on Hortensia Bussi de Allende's ban from the United States], ''New York Times'', 4 March 1983 Bussi de Allende died in 2009. |- |[[Pete Doherty]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |British singer, with numerous drugs-related arrests, denied entry into the United States in June 2010, after spending 10 hours in detention in New York's [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]], despite having a visa.{{cite web|title=Pete Doherty never made it out of the airport.|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2010/06/pete_doherty_ne.html|publisher=Brooklyn Vegan|accessdate=11 June 2010}} |- |[[Kyle Falconer]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|SCO}} |Scottish lead singer for [[The View (band)|The View]]. In 2007 he was convicted of possessing cocaine, resulting in the cancellation of the band's US tour.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/6412105.stm The View singer's cocaine penalty], ''BBC News'', 2 March 2007; accessed 22 May 2008 [[The View (band)|The View]] had been refused entry to the USA, prompting public claims from Falconer that they are permanently banned from both America and Japan. In interviews since the conviction, however, the band have insisted that drugs are no longer an issue and were hoping to tour the States in the near future. Permission for the band to tour the US was granted in 2011.{{cite news|url=http://theviewareonfire.blogspot.com/2008/10/band-talk-to-billy-sloan.html|publisher='Sunday Mail'|title=The View talk to Billy Sloan|date=5 March 2008}} |- |[[William "Leffen" Hjelte]] |{{flagcountry|SWE}} |Swedish professional ''[[Super Smash Bros. Melee]]'' player barred from entering the United States in 2015 just before The Big House 5 tournament based on the [[Electronic System for Travel Authorization|ESTA]], an automated system that determines the eligibility of visitors to travel to the U.S. under the Visa Waiver Program (VWP) due to the lack of a visa which was required as he was sponsored or employed by [[Team SoloMid]], a company based in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.thescoreesports.com/news/4122|title=Leffen denied entry to USA for Smash tournament|first=Matt|last=Demers|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=November 8, 2015}} |- |[[Yusuf Islam]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |British singer formerly known as [[Cat Stevens]] was denied entry into the United States on 21 September 2004, and would remain banned until December 2006, when he was re-admitted without incident to perform at several radio concerts and to conduct interviews promoting his new album.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/20/arts/20yusuf.html?_r=1&oref=slogin|title=Yusuf Islam Steps Back Into Cat Stevens's Old Sound|author=Pareles, Jon|work=The New York Times|date=20 December 2006|accessdate=6 December 2007}} His name had originally been flagged as being on a [[no fly list]]. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officers alerted the [[United States Transportation Security Administration]], which then diverted his flight to [[Bangor, Maine]], where he was detained by officers from the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS).{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A39772-2004Sep21.html|title=Cat Stevens held after D.C. flight diverted|author=Goo, Sara Kehaulani|work=The Washington Post|date= 22 September 2004|accessdate=6 December 2007}} The following day, he was flown back to the United Kingdom. A spokesman for the DHS stated that there had been "concerns of ties he may have to potential terrorist-related activities".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A43282-2004Sep22.html|title=Cat Stevens leaves U.S. after entry denied|author=Goo, Sara Kehaulani|work=The Washington Post|date=23 September 2004|accessdate=6 December 2007}} The singer said that it may have been an error due to the similarity of his name with that of one "Youssef Islam".[[Larry King|King, Larry]] (7 October 2004) {{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0410/07/lkl.01.html|title=Interview With Yusuf Islam, Formerly Cat Stevens, Larry King Live|publisher=CNN|accessdate=7 January 2007}} |- |[[Nigella Lawson]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |Chef author and TV host of ''The Taste'', was barred from a flight out of London to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] on 30 March 2014, due to public revelations of past cocaine use, which became public during her contentious divorce from her second husband.[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/nigella-lawson-barred-boarding-flight-los-angeles-article-1.1743727 "Nigella Lawson barred from flight out of London to Los Angeles" by Nancy Dillon], nydailynews.com; accessed 2 April 2014. |- |[[Diego Maradona]] |{{flagcountry|ARG}} |Former Argentine soccer player and coach. Although he had been to [[Los Angeles]] to play in an exhbition match in 1986, he was then refused entry in 1993 due to cocaine-related arrests and charges in Italy and Argentina; Maradona had been banned from playing soccer/football for 15 months in 1991. Was then allowed entry to the USA in 1994 to play for the Argentine national team who were competing in the [[FIFA World Cup]] in the United States that year; and in 2013 Maradona then attempted to go to Disney World in [[Orlando, Florida]] with his grandson, but was denied a visa at the American consulate in Dubai due to additional drug and assault related charges compiled from 1994 to 2013.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/ABC_Univision/soccer-legend-diego-maradona-denied-us-visa/story?id=19690786|title=This Soccer Legend Was Denied a U.S. Visa|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=17 July 2013|publisher=|accessdate=20 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.myjoyonline.com/pages/news/201307/109655.php|title=Diego Maradona denied entry to Disney World over Visa issues|first=Michael Ofori Amanfo|last=Boateng|publisher=|accessdate=20 November 2016}} He was then denied a visa again after he attempted to go to Florida in 2018 for a court case against his ex-wife Claudia Villafane, whom he accused of stealing $9 million from him and buying 7 apartments in [[Miami]]; the reason given by the American consulate in Dubai was because Maradona had insulted President [[Donald Trump]] on a Venezuelan radio show, even though insulting the President of the United States is not a crime by American federal law. https://soccer.nbcsports.com/2018/02/03/report-maradona-denied-us-entry-after-insulting-trump/ |- |[[Madchild]] (né Shane Bunting) |{{flagcountry|CAN}} |Canadian rapper. In early 2011, it was reported that Bunting was banned from entering the United States, due to alleged links to the [[Hells Angels]] Motorcycle Club. Bunting said he had been detained at an American airport for approximately eight hours before being told he could not enter the United States.[http://www.vancouversun.com/health/Vancouver+Swollen+Members+emcee+Child+banned+from+over+Hells+Angels+association+updated/4064176/story.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426233110/http://www.vancouversun.com/health/Vancouver%2BSwollen%2BMembers%2Bemcee%2BChild%2Bbanned%2Bfrom%2Bover%2BHells%2BAngels%2Bassociation%2Bupdated/4064176/story.html|date=April 26, 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/article/916828--vancouver-rapper-mad-child-barred-from-entering-u-s|title=Vancouver rapper Madchild barred from entering U.S.|last=DeMara|first=Bruce|date=5 January 2011|publisher=Toronto Star|accessdate=10 August 2011}} In July 2013, it was announced that Bunting was once again allowed to enter the United States.{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2013/07/15/exclusive-madchild-speaks-on-being-allowed-to-re-enter-usa|title=Exclusive: Madchild Speaks On Being Allowed To Re-Enter USA - The Source|date=15 July 2013}} |- | [[Nelson Mandela]] |{{flagcountry|RSA}} | South African revolutionary and later president of South Africa. Banned from entering the United States.{{When|date=June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1584635/US-urged-to-end-travel-ban-on-Nelson-Mandela.html|title=US urged to end travel ban on Nelson Mandela|date=9 April 2008|publisher=telegraph.co.uk}} The ban was later lifted.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7484517.stm|title=Mandela taken off US terror list|date=1 July 2008|publisher=bbc.co.uk}} |- | [[Liza Maza]] |{{flagcountry|PHI}} | Flipina activist. U.S. immigration authorities barred her from entering the U.S. on July 9, 2015 before she was to participate in a left-wing conference on U.S. activities in the Philippines. She has accused the U S. of supporting [[Oplan Bantay Laya|human rights violations]] in the [[Philippines]]. She plans to file charges against the U.S. and [[Korean Airlines]], the airline that she was supposed to have taken.{{cite web|url=http://bulatlat.com/main/2015/07/16/us-govt-bars-woman-leader|title=United States government bars woman leader|publisher=Bulatlat.com|date=18 July 2015|accessdate=18 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/705900/womens-group-hits-govt-for-barring-ex-lawmaker-from-leaving-ph|title=Women's Group Hits Government for Barring ex-Lawmaker from Leaving the Philippines|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=15 July 2015|accessdate=17 July 2015}} |- |[[Bernadette Devlin McAliskey]] |{{flagcountry|IRL}} | Irish republican activist McAliskey was banned from entering the United States on 21 February 2003. US Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) officials at O'Hare Airport (Chicago) seized McAliskey who was traveling on a flight from Dublin to New York on the grounds that she posed a "serious threat to national security"; an official stated that she was not allowed to enter due to an "expired visa waiver". She had also been temporarily banned from entering the U.S. in 1983 for fundraising for the [[Irish National Liberation Army]] (INLA).James, Steve (5 March 2003) [http://www.wsws.org/articles/2003/mar2003/devl-m05.shtml "Ireland's Bernadette Devlin McAliskey deported from the US"], World Socialist Website |- |[[Narendra Modi]] |{{flagcountry|IND}} |Indian politician. In 2005, when he was [[Chief Minister of Gujarat]] state in India, Modi was denied a diplomatic A-2 visa to the United States. In addition, the B-1/B-2 visa that had previously been granted to him was revoked, under a section of the [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965|Immigration and Nationality Act]] which makes any foreign government official who was responsible or "directly carried out, at any time, particularly severe violations of religious freedom" ineligible for the visa.{{cite news|title=No entry for Modi into US: visa denied|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2005-03-18/india/27866126_1_business-visa-gujarat-riots-immigration-and-nationality-act|work=The Times of India|accessdate=3 February 2012|date=18 March 2005}} Modi remains the only person ever to be banned to travel to the United States of America under the [[International Religious Freedom Act]] (IRFA) provision of US Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).{{cite news|last1=Mann|first1=James|title=Why Narendra Modi Was Banned From the U.S.|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303380004579520041301275638|accessdate=3 June 2014|date=2 May 2014}} In 2012, A Special Investigation Team (SIT) appointed by the [[Indian Supreme Court]] found no "prosecutable evidence" against Modi and cleared him of all charges. The US visa issue morphed into a diplomatic hurdle in bilateral [[India–United States relations]] when Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister of India in 2014. Modi was issued a visa to visit the US in September 2014 after becoming the [[Prime Minister of India]].{{cite news|title=Modi visits US|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/dougbandow/2014/09/29/indias-prime-minister-narendra-modi-visits-america-washington-should-recognize-another-emerging-great-power/|work=Forbes|accessdate=23 November 2014|date=29 September 2014}} In a volte-face by the US administration, Modi was invited to address a joint session of both houses of the US Congress which he did in June 2016. In 2017, he made a state visit to the US on President Trump's invitation. US President Barack Obama visited India twice to meet Prime Minister Modi, the only US President to have visited India twice in just two years. |- |[[Shane Paul O'Doherty]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|NIR}} |[[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] bomber ((born 1955, Derry, Northern Ireland). One of his bombs injured a member of the British Cabinet, [[Reginald Maudling]]. He sent a letter bomb to 10 Downing Street, which did not explode. Other locales where his bombs did detonate include the [[London Stock Exchange]], the [[Bank of England]], and an otherwise unidentified government building, injuring several people, including a security guard who lost an eye and a hand. O'Doherty sent a bomb to Bishop [[Gerard William Tickle|Gerard Tickle]], the Roman Catholic chaplain to the [[British Army]], after reading a newspaper story which purportedly quoted the bishop as stating that British soldiers did nothing wrong on Bloody Sunday. The bomb was stuffed into a hollowed-out Bible but failed to detonate. His [[United States]] citizen wife, Michelle Sweeney, tried to sponsor him for a visa, which was denied based on O'Doherty's criminal record. The marriage was later annulled.Cullen, Kevin. (7 August 2005) [http://www.boston.com/news/globe/magazine/articles/2005/08/07/the_redemption_of_shane_paul_odoherty/?page=full Shane Paul O'Doherty profile in ''The Boston Globe''][http://www.derryjournal.com/news/local/i-met-hain-shane-paul-1-3471608 Shane Paul O'Doherty profile in ''The Derry Journal''], 2 February 2012.{{#tag:ref|O'Doherty entered studies for the priesthood after receiving a waiver from the Vatican with the assistance of the Archbishop of Dublin, [[Diarmuid Martin]], which was required due to his attempt on the life of Bishop Tickle in 1972.|group=N}} |- | [[Alexi Ogando]] | {{flagcountry|Dominican Republic}} |[[Major League Baseball]] player (relief pitcher) admitted his involvement in an immigration marriage fraud ring. He was banned in 2009 from entering the United States for five years, limiting him to winter ball, the Dominican Summer League and international tournaments.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/baseball/rangers/stories/030908dnsporangdominicans.353b912.html |title=Role in Fraud Ruins Dreams for Texas Rangers' Prospects |author=Evan Grant |date=9 March 2009 |publisher=Dallas Morning News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206201539/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/baseball/rangers/stories/030908dnsporangdominicans.353b912.html |archivedate=February 6, 2010 }} |- |[[Pogo (electronic musician)|Pogo]] |{{flagcountry|RSA}}
{{flagcountry|AUS}} |[[South Africa]]n-born [[Australia]]n electronic music artist/producer. Pogo, born as Nick Bertke, was incarcerated for three weeks – two weeks in a county jail and another week in a federal detention centre – after being apprehended without a working visa while touring in America in September 2011. His 10-year ban took effect the following month.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/aussie-music-producer-nick-bertke-aka-pogo-jailed-banned-from-us/story-e6frfn09-1226599401426#ixzz2S9r7z03l|title=Aussie music producer Nick Bertke, aka Pogo, jailed, banned from US|publisher=|accessdate=20 November 2016}} |- |[[Marion Price]] |{{flagcountry|IRL}} |[[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] bomber who was convicted of causing explosions in London on 8 March 1973, was refused a visa to enter the USA in 1999. She had been due to speak at a fundraising event in New York that had been organised by the Irish Freedom Committee.[https://belfastchildis.wordpress.com/2015/12/14/15th-december-deaths-events-in-northern-ireland-troubles Marion Price banned from entering the US], belfastchildis.wordpress.com; accessed 19 December 2015. |- |[[Tariq Ramadan]] |{{flagcountry|SWI}} | Swiss academic, educator and author (''Western Muslims and the Future of Islam'') was banned from entering the United States from 2004–2010. He purportedly was given various reasons for the ban, including having "endorsed terrorism" and "violated the [[USA Patriot Act]]". Later he was banned for having contributed money to a French charity supporting humanitarian work in the Palestinian territories between 1998 and 2002, which was deemed, in 2003, to have the charities in question provided money to [[Hamas]]. In 2010, the ban was lifted.[http://www.democracynow.org/2010/4/9/once_banned_muslim_scholar_tariq_ramadan "Tariq Ramadan's ban from U.S. lifted"], ''Washington Post'', 9 April 2010 |- |[[Tarek William Saab]] |{{flagcountry|VEN}} |Venezuelan politician and lawyer. Saab was refused an entry visa to the United States in 2002. ''Reuters'' reported that Saab told local television he had been denied the visa because a [[U.S. State Department]] report "identified him as 'an individual linked to international subversion'". According to Venezuela's ''El Universal'', Saab gave a press conference, in which he referred to published information that he had been denied the visa as a consequence of his ties with international terrorist organizations. Saab denied that he was associated with international terrorism or subversive groups.[http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2002/10/03/pol_art_03106EE.shtml Saab denied visa to the USA], eluniversal.com; accessed 8 July 2015. |- | [[Mark Thatcher]] |{{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} |Son of former British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]], Sir Mark Thatcher was denied a [[Permanent residence (United States)|green card]] (permanent residency visa), although then married to a U.S. citizen, Louise Thatcher (née Burgdorf), due to his guilty plea in January 2005 in [[South Africa]] to breaking anti-mercenary legislation in South Africa by investing in an aircraft "without taking proper investigations into what it would be used for", admitting in court that he had paid the money, but said he was under the impression it was to be invested in an air ambulance service to help impoverished Africans. The judge rejected this explanation and Thatcher was fined [[South African rand|R]]3,000,000 [[rand (currency)|rand]] and received a four-year [[suspended sentence|suspended jail sentence]]. On 3 April 2005, Thatcher, then living with his mother in London, announced that his family home would be in Europe after he was refused a residence visa to live in the United States as a result of his guilty plea in the Equatorial Guinea affair.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4169557.stm BBC report on Mark Thatcher's plea bargain in re Equatorial Guinea conspiracy], 13 January 2005. |- | [[Gerard Ungerman]] |{{flagcountry|France}} |French filmmaker banned from re-entering the United States for 15 months beginning on 13 December 2010. After being "stuck" in Paris for five months disputing with U.S. immigration authorities over his right to return to California, where he had lived for almost 20 years, he was officially barred from re-entering the U.S., despite the [[Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS)'s approval of his immigrant visa petition, which should have allowed him to return. U.S. immigration authorities in Europe charged that he had been living in the U.S. illegally and was therefore ineligible for the approved green card (permanent residency visa) for which he had traveled to the U.S. Consulate in Paris to pick up per the directive from DHS. ''"What I didn't know is that I should not have left the country"'', Ungerman later realized, ''"but I should have worked out with a lawyer to convert my immigrant-visa approval into an actual immigrant status from inside the country. Instead I went out to Paris, where I had been 'invited' to pick up my visa at the U.S. Consulate. By doing that, I stepped into a bear trap because the consul there accused me [in July] of having stayed illegally and told me I was ineligible for my visa for 10 years and couldn't go back home"'', but was eventually allowed to return to the U.S., arriving on 12 October 2011.LaPado-Breglia, Christine G.K. (23 December 2010) [http://www.newsreview.com/chico/chico-filmmaker-stuck-in-france/content?oid=1894337 Filmmaker Gerard Ungerman stuck in France], newsreview.com |- |[[Kurt Waldheim|Kurt]] and [[Elisabeth Waldheim]] |{{flagcountry|AUT}} | Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat and politician; former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]], and President of Austria (1986–1992), and his wife Elisabeth, were officially deemed ''[[persona non grata|personae non gratae]]'' by the United States and excluded from entering United States territory due to their Nazi affiliations and activities during [[World War II]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL2351006420070623?pageNumber=2|title=Waldheim, ex-UN leader and Nazi, buried in Austria|work=Reuters|date=23 June 2007}} In 1987, the couple was placed on a [[Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System|watch list]] of persons banned from entering the United States and remained on the list until their deaths in 2007 and 2017. |- | [[Amy Winehouse]] | {{flagcountry|UK}}
{{flagcountry|ENG}} | British singer banned from the USA in 2009 for drug convictions and for assault. A year and a half after she had been barred from entering the country in 2007 to attend the Grammys due to a drug rap, U.S. authorities refused to grant her a work visa in 2009 to perform at the Coachella festival. She was ordered to appear at the City of Westminster Magistrates Court to face a common assault charge (dating from September 2008) on 17 March 2009. Winehouse had been previously prohibited from playing in the U.S. after she was arrested in [[Norway]] on a drug charge, and ended up performing live via satellite.[https://archive.is/20130130042813/http://www.nypost.com/p/blogs/popwrap/item_Wm98wsfq4BptRxSbEp4OxO "Amy Winehouse banned from U.S. for various reasons on various occasions"], nypost.com; accessed 25 October 2015. Winehouse died in 2011. |} ==See also== {{Portal|Law}} * [[List of people deported from the United States]] * [[List of denaturalized former citizens of the United States]] * [[Illegal immigration to the United States]] * [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=N}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ice.gov/ U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement website] {{Immigration to the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:People barred or excluded from the United States, List of}} [[Category:Immigration to the United States]] [[Category:Excluded people]] [[Category:Lists of people by legal status]] [[Category:Lists of people by place|United States]] [[Category:People deported from the United States|*]] [[Category:United States immigration law]]

page.title: List of people influenced by Ayn Rand

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} Novelist and philosopher [[Ayn Rand]] (1905–1982) has had a significant influence on a variety of people, including writers, artists and political figures.<ref>{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=111–26}}; {{harvnb|Merrill|2013|pp=3–6, 8–13}}; {{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=411–22}}</ref> Individuals included in this list meet at least one of the following criteria: * they have identified at some point in their lives as followers of Rand's philosophy of [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]]; or * they have been involved with self-identified Objectivist organizations, such as the [[Nathaniel Branden Institute]], the [[Ayn Rand Institute]], or [[The Atlas Society]]; or * they have described Rand or her works as an important influence on their lives. Individuals who do not meet those criteria, but have mentioned being a "[[Fan (person)|fan]]" or enjoying Rand's works, are not included.
{{Compact ToC |side=yes |seealso=yes |refs=yes |extlinks=yes}}
==A== * [[John Aglialoro]]<ref name="Merrill-p3">{{harvnb|Merrill|2013|p=3}}</ref> (1943– ), an American businessman and film producer. * [[John A. Allison IV]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2012/01/12/where-are-champions-freedom/ |title=Where are the champions of freedom? |first=John |last=Stossel |date=January 12, 2012 |publisher=FoxNews.com |accessdate=January 2, 2013}}</ref> (1948– ), an American businessman and the former CEO and president of the [[Cato Institute]]. * [[Martin Anderson (economist)|Martin Anderson]]<ref name="Branden-p310">{{harvnb|Branden|1986|p=310}}</ref> (1936–2015), an economist, policy analyst, author, and advisor to President [[Ronald Reagan]].
==B== [[File:Bob Barr-2008 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=|Former congressman [[Bob Barr]] was introduced to Rand's writings by his mother.<ref>{{cite news |first=Melinda |last=Henneberger |title=The Georgia Republican Who Uses the I-Word |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/09/us/the-georgia-republican-who-uses-the-i-word.html |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 9, 1998 |accessdate=December 22, 2015}}</ref>]] * [[Bob Barr]]<ref>{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=124}}</ref> (1948– ), a former member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] who was the [[Libertarian He is a professor at [[George Mason University]] and is co-author of the economics [[blog]] ''Marginal Revolution''. * [[Chris Tame]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/apr/05/guardianobituaries.mainsection |title=Obituary: Chris Tame |first=Marc |last=Glendening |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 5, 2006 |accessdate=December 23, 2015}}</ref> (1949–2006), a British libertarian political activist who founded the [[Libertarian Alliance]]. * [[Peter Thiel]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2024761/Atlas-Shrugged-Silicon-Valley-billionaire-reveals-plan-launch-floating-start-country-coast-San-Francisco.html |title=Floating cities: PayPal billionaire plans to build a whole new libertarian colony off the coast of San Francisco |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=April 28, 2013}}</ref> (1967– ), an American entrepreneur and venture capitalist who co-founded [[PayPal]] and [[Palantir Technologies]]. * [[Clarence Thomas]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Thomas |first=Clarence |title=[[My Grandfather's Son: A Memoir]] |location=New York |publisher=Harper Perennial |year=2007 |pages=62, 187 |isbn=0-06-056556-X |oclc=191930033}}</ref> (1948– ), an [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States]]. He previously served as an assistant secretary at the [[U.S. Department of Education]], chairman of the [[Equal Employment Opportunity]] Commission, and on the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]]. * [[Hunter S. Thompson]]<ref>{{cite book |title=The Proud Highway: Saga of a Desperate Southern Gentleman, 1955–1967 (The Fear and Loathing Letters, Vol. 1) |last=Thompson |first=Hunter S. |authorlink=Hunter S. Thompson |date=April 7, 1998 |publisher=[[Ballantine Books]] |pages=69–70 |isbn=0345377966 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MBZFIHiJgI8C&pg=PA69}}</ref> (1937–2005), an American author and founder of the [[gonzo journalism]] movement. His works include ''[[Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas]]'' and ''[[The Rum Diary (novel)|The Rum Diary]]''. * [[Monroe Trout]]<ref>{{harvnb|Walker|1999|p=333}}</ref> (1962– ), a retired financial speculator and hedge fund manager.
==V== * [[Vince Vaughn]]<ref>{{cite web|title=An Interview with Vince Vaughn |year=1999 |publisher=Judd Handler |url=http://www.writeonjudd.com/portfolio/an-interview-with-vince-vaughn/ |archivedate=January 26, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DxSAtp4T?url=http://www.writeonjudd.com/portfolio/an-interview-with-vince-vaughn/ |quote=''The last book I read was the book I’ve been rereading most of my life, [[The Fountainhead]].'' |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> (1970– ), an American actor, screenwriter, and producer.
==W== [[File:Jimmy Wales in August 2006.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=|Wikipedia co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]] ran an email list for discussion of Rand's philosophy.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Runciman |first=David |url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v31/n10/runc01_.html |title=Like Boiling a Frog |journal=[[London Review of Books]] |date=May 28, 2009 |accessdate=December 22, 2015}}</ref>]] * [[Jimmy Wales]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Why Is This Man Smiling? |last=Deutschman |first=Alan |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/59260/why-man-smiling |work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |date=April 1, 2007 |accessdate=January 2, 2013}}</ref> (1966– ), an American [[Internet entrepreneur]] who co-founded [[Wikipedia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Brain Scan: The Free-knowledge Fundamentalist |url=http://www.economist.com/science/tq/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11484062 |work=The Economist |date=June 5, 2008 |accessdate=December 22, 2015}}</ref> * [[Don Watkins]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ari.aynrand.org/experts/don-watkins |title=Don Watkins |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute |accessdate=December 22, 2015}}</ref> an American author, columnist, and professional speaker. In 2006 he was appointed a [[fellow]] at the Ayn Rand Institute.
==See also== * [[Objectivist movement]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
===Works cited=== * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=I Chose Liberty: Autobiographies of Contemporary Libertarians |editor-first=Walter |editor-last=Block |editor-link=Walter Block |year=2010 |publisher=[[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] |location=Auburn, Alabama |isbn=978-1-61016-002-5 |url=https://mises.org/library/i-chose-liberty-autobiographies-contemporary-libertarians}} * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=[[The Passion of Ayn Rand]] |last=Branden |first=Barbara |authorlink=Barbara Branden |location=Garden City, New York |publisher=Doubleday & Company |year=1986 |isbn=0-385-19171-5 |oclc=12614728}} * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=Ayn Rand |last=Gladstein |first=Mimi Reisel |authorlink=Mimi Reisel Gladstein |location=New York |publisher=Continuum |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-8264-4513-1 |oclc=319595162 |series=Major Conservative and Libertarian Thinkers series}} * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=Ayn Rand Explained: From Tyranny to Tea Party |first=Ronald E. |last=Merrill |others=Revised and updated by Marsha Familaro Enright |location=Chicago |publisher=Open Court |year=2013 |isbn=978-0-8126-9798-8}} * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=[[The Ayn Rand Cult]] |last=Walker |first=Jeff |location=La Salle, Illinois |publisher=Open Court Publishing |year=1999 |isbn=0-8126-9390-6 |oclc=39914039}} * {{Cite book |ref=harv |title=Ayn Rand Nation: The Hidden Struggle for America's Soul |last=Weiss |first=Gary |authorlink=Gary Weiss |location=New York |publisher=St. Martin's Press |year=2012 |isbn=978-0-312-59073-4 |oclc=740628885}}
