[[National University of Physical Education and Sport of Ukraine]] |website = {{url|klichko.org|Official website}} |term_start = 5 June 2014 |term_end = |term_start1 = 25 June 2014 |term_end1 = |office2 = [[Kiev City Council|Deputy of the Kiev City Council]] |convocation2 = [[Ukrainian local elections, 2006|5th session]] |constituency2 = [[Ukrainian Democratic Alliance for Reform|Klitschko Bloc "PORA–ROP"]] |term_start2 = April 2006 |term_end2 = June 2008 |convocation3 = [[Kiev local election, 2008|6th session]] |constituency3 = [[Ukrainian Democratic Alliance for Reform|Vitali Klitschko Bloc]] |term_start3 = June 2008 |term_end3 = December 2012 |office4 = [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] |convocation4 = [[7th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|7th convocation]] |constituency4 = [[Ukrainian Democratic Alliance for Reform|UDAR]], No.1{{cite web |title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the VII convocation |url=http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/15664/8 |website=Official portal |publisher=Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine |accessdate=22 December 2014 |language=Ukrainian}} |term_start4 = 12 December 2012 |term_end4 = 5 June 2014 }} '''Vitali Volodymyrovych Klitschko''' ({{IPAc-en|v|ᵻ|ˈ|t|æ|l|i|_|ˈ|k|l|ɪ|tʃ|k|oʊ}}; {{lang-uk|Віта́лій Володи́мирович Кличко́}}, {{IPA-uk|ʋiˈtɑlʲij klɪtʃˈkɔ|}}; born 19 July 1971){{cite web|url=http://www.klitschko.com/vitali-wladimir|title=Vitali Klitschko|website=Official website of Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko|accessdate=26 February 2014}} is a Ukrainian politician and former [[professional boxer]]. He currently serves as [[Mayor of Kiev]][http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/208052.html Vitali Klitschko sworn in as Kyiv mayor], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (5 June 2014) and head of the [[Kiev City State Administration]], having held both offices since June 2014. Klitschko is a former leader of the [[Petro Poroshenko Bloc]]http://www.unian.info/kiev/1356522-klitschko-resigns-as-bpp-solidarnist-chairman.html and a former [[Verkhovna Rada|Member of the Ukrainian Parliament]].[http://ukrainianweek.com/Politics/60928 "You Scratch My Back, and I’ll Scratch Yours"], ''[[The Ukrainian Week]]'' (26 September 2012)[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20031821 Q&A:Ukrainian parliamentary election], [[BBC News]] (23 October 2012)[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20113616 Ukraine election:President Yanukovych party claims win], [[BBC News]] (29 October 2012)[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/parties-spend-over-hr-600-million-on-elections-according-to-report-316205.html "Parties spend over Hr 600 million on elections, according to report"], ''[[Kiev Post]]'' (16 November 2012) He became actively involved in [[Ukrainian politics]] in 2005 and combined this with his professional boxing career until his retirement from the sport in 2013.Furman, Luke (25 December 2013) [http://www.boxingscene.com/vitali-klitschko-rule-out-another-ring-return--73073 Vitali Klitschko Won't Rule Out Another Ring Return – Boxing News]. Boxingscene.com. Retrieved 10 July 2014. As a boxer, Klitschko is a three-time world [[heavyweight]] champion, the [[list of WBC world champions#Heavyweight|second longest reigning WBC heavyweight champion of all time]], has the [[longest reigning heavyweight champions|fifth longest combined world championship reign in history]] at 2,735 days, the [[List of WBC world champions#Heavyweight|third longest individual WBC heavyweight title streak of all time]] at 9 consecutive defenses and the [[longest reigning heavyweight boxing champions#Most wins in heavyweight title bouts in different eras|4th longest combined title streak in the modern heavyweight history]] at 15 title bouts. He held the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] title from 1999 to 2000; the [[The Ring (magazine)|''Ring'' magazine]] title from 2004 to 2005; and the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] title twice, from 2004 to 2005 and from 2008 to 2013. Standing at 2.01 metres (6 feet 7 inches), Klitschko was renowned for having exceptional ring dominance. With an 87% [[knockout]] percentage, he holds one of the highest knockout-to-fight ratios of any world champion in heavyweight boxing history, while also possessing a highly durable [[chin (combat sports)|chin]]. His two losses came via a shoulder injury and a deep cut above his eye, both of which were recorded as [[technical knockout|stoppages]] rather than outright knockouts; in both fights he was leading on the judges' scorecards. Klitschko is the only heavyweight boxer to have reigned as world champion in three different decades. Along with [[Oliver McCall]], he is also the only world heavyweight champion to have never been [[knockdown (boxing)|knocked down]] in any fight. Klitschko and [[George Foreman]] are the only heavyweight boxers in history to defend a world title after turning 40.http://www.thesweetscience.com/feature-articles/17760-vitali-klitschko-retires-to-pursue-politics Being the first professional boxing world champion to hold a PhD degree, and in reference to his punching power, Klitschko's nickname was "Dr. Ironfist". His younger brother, [[Wladimir Klitschko|Wladimir]], is a former unified world heavyweight champion. From 2006 until 2015, Vitali and Wladimir dominated heavyweight boxing, a period typically known as the "[[Klitschko brothers|Klitschko Era]]" of the division.http://www.sherdog.com/news/articles/Boxing-Wladimir-Klitschkos-Loss-Signals-End-of-Era-96845http://www.boxinginsider.com/columns/can-mariusz-wach-end-the-klitschko-era-of-dominance/ Klitschko formally began his political career in 2006 when he placed second in the Kiev mayoral race. In 2010, he founded the party [[Ukrainian Democratic Alliance for Reform]] (UDAR) and was elected into parliament for this party [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|in 2012]]. He was a leading figure in the 2013–2014 [[Euromaidan]] protests, and he announced his possible candidacy for the [[President of Ukraine|Ukrainian presidency]] but later withdrew and endorsed [[Petro Poroshenko]].{{#tag:ref|[[Petro Poroshenko]] was [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|elected]] [[President of Ukraine]] on 25 May 2014.{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20140529-707812.html |title=Petro Poroshenko to Be Inaugurated as Ukraine President June 7 |author=Lukas Alpert |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=29 May 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529234158/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20140529-707812.html |archivedate=29 May 2014 }}|group=nb}} He was elected Mayor of Kiev on 25 May 2014.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/207829.html Klitschko officially announced as winner of Kyiv mayor election], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (4 June 2014) Klitschko headed the election list of the winner of the [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], the [[Petro Poroshenko Bloc]], but he gave up his parliamentary seat to stay on as Mayor of Kiev. On 28 August 2015 the [[UDAR]] party merged into Petro Poroshenko Bloc.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/286616.html Klitschko becomes leader of Petro Poroshenko Bloc 'Solidarity' party], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 August 2015) Klitschko thus became the new party leader. Klitschko was reelected as mayor on 15 November 2015.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/304188.html Kyiv Mayor Klitschko reelected with 66.5% of vote, 100% of ballot protocols processed – preliminary data]. En.interfax.com.ua [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2015-11-16). Retrieved on 2015-11-29. ==Kickboxing and amateur boxing career (1985–1996)== Originally, Klitschko was an amateur [[kickboxing|kickboxer]] with a record of 34–2 with 22 knockouts. *In 1992, he was defeated in the final of the European Kickboxing Championships +89 kg light contact division by Englishman [[Pelé Reid]] when he was knocked out by a spin kick to the jaw.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9n7zExsuCRU Pele Reid spin kick against V. Klitschko in world championship, Full fight]. YouTube. Retrieved 10 July 2014. *In 1993, he defeated [[Ryushi Yanagisawa]] in the Japanese [[mixed martial arts]] promotion [[Pancrase]] under [[World Kickboxing Association|WKA]] Special Rules (no low kicks) via R5 decision. *In 1994, he defeated Richard Vince by second-round KO to retain his [[International Sport Karate Association|ISKA]] World [[Super Heavyweight]] title. *In 1995, he was a super heavyweight silver medalist at the [[1995 World Amateur Boxing Championships]]: **Defeated Gitas Juškevičius (Lithuania) RSC-2 **Defeated [[Attila Levin]] (Sweden) RET-2 **Defeated [[Rene Monse]] (Germany) PTS (6–5) **Lost to [[Alexei Lezin]] (Russia) PTS (3–12) *In 1995, he was a super heavyweight gold medalist at the [[World Military Championships]] in [[Ariccia]], Italy: **Defeated Kenneth Horsley (USA) RET-1 **Defeated [[Svilen Rusinov]] (Bulgaria) RSC-1 **Defeated Drago Mijić (Croatia) WO **Defeated [[Alexei Lezin]] (Russia) PTS (10–6) '''Amateur boxing record''': 195 wins, 15 losses. '''kickboxing record''': 34–2 with 22 knockouts. He was a kickboxing world champion six times (four in professionals and two in amateurs).{{cite web |url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/boxing-news/Vitali-Klitschko-Interview.php |title=Interview: Head 2 Head with Vitali Klitschko |publisher=Eastsideboxing.com |accessdate=27 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914052836/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/boxing-news/Vitali-Klitschko-Interview.php |archive-date=14 September 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 1996, he turned boxing professional. ==Professional boxing career (1996–2013)== {{BLP sources|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox boxer | image = Vitali Klitschko by Slawek.jpg{{!}}border | caption = Klitschko with the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] title, 2011 | nickname = Dr. Ironfist | weight = [[Heavyweight]] | height = {{height|m=2.01|precision=0}}[http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?cat=boxer&human_id=7033 Boxing | BoxRec]. boxrec.com. Retrieved 2011-05-10. | reach = {{convert|203|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} | nationality = Ukrainian | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|7|19|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Belovodskoye]], [[Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic|Kirghiz SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] (now Kyrgyzstan) | style = [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] | total = 47 | wins = 45 | KO = 41 | losses = 2 | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Men's [[amateur boxing]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{UKR}} }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Military World Games]]}} {{MedalGold | [[1995 Military World Games|1995 Rome]] | [[Super-heavyweight]]}} {{MedalCompetition | [[World Amateur Boxing Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver | [[1995 World Amateur Boxing Championships|1995 Berlin]] | Super-heavyweight}} }} As an [[amateur boxing|amateur]], Klitschko won the [[super-heavyweight]] championship at the first [[World Military Games]] in Italy in 1995. In the same year he won a silver medal at the [[1995 World Amateur Boxing Championships|World Championships]] in Berlin, Germany, where he was defeated by Russia's [[Alexei Lezin]] in the final. In his autobiography, published in Germany in 2004, the boxer revealed that he tested positive for a banned [[anabolic steroid|steroid]] in 1996. He attributed the presence of the drug to treatment of a leg injury, but was dismissed from the Ukrainian boxing team and missed the [[1996 Summer Olympics|Atlanta Olympics]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/2389404/Boxing-Klitschko-admits-steroid-abuse.html|title=Klitschko admits steroid abuse|date=2 November 2004|work=Telegraph Sport|accessdate=8 April 2010|location=London|first=Bob|last=Mee}} His brother Wladimir moved up from [[heavyweight]] to super heavyweight to take his place in the squad and won the Olympic gold medal. His amateur record was 195–15 with 80 knockouts. ===WBO heavyweight champion=== Klitschko began his professional boxing career in 1996, winning his first twenty-four fights by either early [[knockout]] or [[technical knockout]]. He and Wladimir signed with the German athlete-promotion company Universum. With both brothers holding PhDs and being multilingual, their refined and articulate personalities made for mainstream marketability when they moved to Germany and Universum. In time, they became national celebrities in their adopted home country. In his 25th pro fight on 26 June 1999, Klitschko won the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] [[Heavyweight]] title from [[Herbie Hide]] of the United Kingdom by a second-round knockout. He successfully defended the title twice. He defeated Ed Mahone by knockout in the third round and beat [[Obed Sullivan]], who retired after the ninth round. ===Title loss to Byrd=== {{Main|Vitali Klitschko vs. Chris Byrd}} By April 2000 Vitali Klitschko was unbeaten and a rising star in the heavyweight division, having won all 27 of his contests by knockout. On 1 April, Klitschko had a third title defense against the American [[Chris Byrd]], who was a late replacement.{{cite web| last =Songalia |first =Ryan |title =Byrd: Vitali Klitschko Quit, He Knew I Would Stop Him!|publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =28 September 2011 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/byrd-vitali-klitschko-quit-he-knew-i-stop-him--44306 |accessdate =24 January 2015}} Byrd made himself a difficult target and tried to thwart Klitschko's offense by being elusive. Klitschko won most of the rounds and was heading towards a comprehensive points victory when he suffered a serious shoulder injury. After the ninth round, Klitschko notified his corner that he had a shoulder pain and [[submission (combat sport)|threw in the towel]], thus handing Klitschko his first defeat and awarding Byrd the win by RTD. At the time of the stoppage, Klitschko had won 8 of 9 rounds on one judge's scorecard, and 7 of 9 on the two others. Klitschko, who was later diagnosed with a torn [[rotator cuff]], received much criticism for quitting the fight. Klitschko rebounded from his loss to Byrd by reeling off five victories in a row, earning himself a shot at [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] Heavyweight Champion [[Lennox Lewis]]. ===Klitschko vs. Lennox Lewis=== {{Main|Lennox Lewis vs. Vitali Klitschko}} The fight between Lewis and Klitschko was to take place in December 2003, and Klitschko signed for a tune-up fight on 21 June 2003 as part of the undercard of Lewis' fight with [[Kirk Johnson]] for the [[International Boxing Organization|IBO]] title, as the WBC would not sanction the fight for their title. Johnson, however, pulled out of the fight due to injury and Klitschko, due to his being in training for a fight on the same day as Lewis, took the fight on short notice. Immediately after he accepted, the WBC elected to sanction the fight as a title match and Lewis' ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'' title was also up for grabs in addition to his [[lineal championship|lineal]] title. Klitschko, a 4–1 underdog, dominated the early going with many harder punches. He stunned Lewis in the second round with two hard rights, leaving a cut under on Lennox's left eye.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/22/sports/boxing-lewis-cuts-the-deepest-and-retains-his-title.html?scp=10&sq=klitschko%20lewis&st=cse|title=Lewis Cuts the Deepest and Retains His Title|last=Freeman|first=Mike|date=22 June 2003|work=The New York Times|accessdate=22 June 2009}} In the third, Lewis landed a big right hand that opened a deep cut above Klitschko's left eye. Before the seventh round, the ringside doctor inspected the wound and deemed it severe enough to threaten eye damage if struck again, stopping the fight despite Klitschko's pleas to continue. Klitschko was ahead on all three judges' scorecards 58–56 (4 rounds to 2) at the time of the stoppage, but because the wound was a result of punches from Lewis, Lewis won by [[technical knockout]]. Negotiations for a 6 December rematch began.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/boxing-lewis-set-to-retire-after-rematch-with-klitschko-588533.html|title=Boxing: Lewis set to retire after re-match with Klitschko|date=31 July 2003|work=The Independent|location=London, UK|first=Kieran|last=Daley|accessdate=27 May 2010}} After negotiations collapsed, Vitali defeated Kirk Johnson in a WBC Eliminator bout on 6 December date,[http://boxrec.com/media/index.php/Vitali_Klitschko_vs._Kirk_Johnson Vitali Klitschko vs. Kirk Johnson – Boxrec Boxing Encyclopaedia]. Boxrec.com. Retrieved 19 April 2011. setting up a mandatory rematch with Lewis. In January 2004, the WBC announced that it would strip Lewis of the belt if he let pass a 15 March deadline to sign for a rematch with Vitali.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2004-01-25-lewis-wbc_x.htm|title=WBC to Lewis: Fight or else|work=USA Today|first1=Dan|last1=Rafael|date=27 January 2004}} Shortly thereafter, Lewis announced his retirement and vacated the title. For years after this fight, Klitschko would still occasionally call out Lewis, despite the fact that Lewis has been retired since early 2004, for a rematch.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=16423.html|title=Vitali Klitschko Only Interested in Lennox Lewis, Valuev|publisher=Boxingscene.com|accessdate=1 November 2009}} Around this time the Klitschko brothers moved from [[Hamburg]], Germany to Los Angeles. In January 2004 they notified Universum that they would not re-sign when their contracts expired in April. Universum sued the brothers, arguing that their recent injuries had triggered a clause binding them beyond April. The suit was ultimately resolved in favor of the Klitschkos in November 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=21793&more=1|title=Klitschko Bros KO Universum|publisher=Eastsideboxing.com|accessdate=11 November 2009}} ===WBC and ''The Ring'' heavyweight champion=== Klitschko faced South African [[Corrie Sanders]] on 24 April 2004 for the WBC heavyweight championship and ''The Ring'' belts that had been vacated by Lewis. Sanders had stopped younger brother Wladimir in the second round (TKO) on 8 March 2003. Klitschko took a heavy shot in round one by Sanders and almost knocked down right at the end of the round, but by using upper-body movement and accurate punching he broke down Sanders over the following rounds, forcing referee Jon Schorle to stop the bout in the eighth. Vitali landed 60% of his power punches. ===Klitschko vs. Williams=== Klitschko's first WBC title defense was against British boxer [[Danny Williams (boxer)|Danny Williams]]. Williams had become suddenly marketable from a KO over [[Mike Tyson]] in round 4. Klitschko scored a technical knockout against Williams in 8 rounds on 11 December 2004, while wearing an orange cloth to show support for the Ukrainian presidential opposition movement. Klitschko knocked Williams down in the 1st, 3rd, 7th, and 8th rounds before the fight was stopped. Immediately afterward, Klitschko dedicated his victory to democracy in his native Ukraine and also to the Ukrainian presidential candidate [[Viktor Yushchenko]], whom he supported in 26 December 2004, [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|election revote]].{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E02E3DF1F31F931A25751C1A9629C8B63&fta=y|title=Klitschko Remains a Champion in a Dominating Show of Force|work=The New York Times|date=12 December 2004|accessdate=1 November 2009}} [[File:Klitschko.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Brothers [[Wladimir Klitschko|Wladimir]] (left) and Vitali (right) Klitschko sporting the colors of the [[Orange Revolution]]]] ===2005–2007 retirement=== On 9 November 2005, Klitschko announced his retirement from professional boxing and vacated his title. He had been training to fight [[Hasim Rahman]], however, nine days before the fight, he injured his leg while sparring. He snapped his [[anterior cruciate ligament]], which with surgery would take up to a year to heal and possibly prove career ending. To avoid keeping the title out of use he retired. The WBC was grateful for his consideration. On other occasions he cited regrets about his suddenly mounting injuries, a desire to leave the sport while still on top and political aspirations in his home country of Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2220413|title=Rahman: If not Vitali, bring on Wlad|publisher=ESPN|date=10 November 2005|accessdate=1 November 2009}} Following his retirement, the WBC conferred "champion emeritus" status on Klitschko, and assured him he would become the mandatory challenger if and when he decided to return.{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Gareth A.|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/3184341/David-Haye-confident-he-can-take-down-both-Klitschko-brothers.html|title=David Haye confident he can take down both Klitschko brothers|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=12 October 2008|accessdate=1 November 2009|location=London, UK}} ===Second WBC heavyweight championship=== On 3 August 2008 the WBC awarded Klitschko a chance to regain his WBC Heavyweight title. After Vitali's retirement, his younger brother had established dominance in the division, winning two of the four world titles available. The reigning WBC Champion was [[Samuel Peter]] (who had lost a decision to Wladimir in a thrilling fight in 2005). At the time, there was interest in a potential Peter vs. Wladimir unification match. Instead, Vitali took advantage of his champion emeritus status and secured a title challenge against Peter. The fight was arranged on 11 October 2008 at [[O2 World (Berlin)|O2 World, Berlin]]. It would be one of the most anticipated heavyweight fights in the past few years. Both men had a rightful claim to being the champion and the stakes for the future of the heavyweight division were high. Despite some questioning Vitali's decision to return after four years, he managed to regain his title in dominating fashion. Klitschko had Peter intimidated from the first round and stunned him with accurate hard punches. Klitschko kept the hard-punching Nigerian off with an effective left jab and took control in the center of the ring. Over eight rounds, Klitschko completely dismantled and outfought the younger champion. After the eighth round, Peter slumped on his stool, shook his head and asked that the bout be stopped. With the Samuel Peter victory, Klitschko technically became one of the few men to ever hold a version of the World Heavyweight Championship three times – WBO (1999–2000), WBC (2004–2005) and WBC (2008–2012). ===Klitschko vs. Gómez, Arreola, Johnson=== On 21 March 2009, Klitschko defeated [[Juan Carlos Gómez]] by TKO in the ninth round. Gómez tried to use his movement to thwart Vitali, but seemed unable to cope with the power and physical strength of his opponent. As the rounds progressed, Klitschko began imposing himself on Gómez more and more. Gómez soon became wary of Klitschko's power and also began to tire physically. By the sixth round, Vitali was in total control. The end came when the referee stopped the fight in the ninth round as Gómez appeared unable to withstand any more hits. On 26 September, Klitschko earned a one-sided TKO victory over [[Chris Arreola]] at the Staples Center in Los Angeles when Arreola's trainer, Henry Ramirez, asked the referee to stop the fight.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/boxing/8274233.stm|title=Dominant Klitschko beats Arreola|date=27 September 2009|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 September 2009}} Arreola was considered at the time one of the division's hardest punchers; however, Klitschko kept Arreola at bay with his left jab and hit him almost at will with his right. Arreola had been influenced by Samuel Peter's defeat to Klitschko in 2008, in which Peter had tried to box from the outside. He therefore employed a game-plan which involved applying constant pressure to Vitali in order to force him into a high tempo fight. Despite his best efforts, the bout became one sided very quickly. Klitschko consistently proved himself faster, sharper and much fitter than Arreola. On 12 December, Vitali defeated [[Kevin Johnson (boxer)|Kevin Johnson]] by unanimous decision, winning almost every round. Johnson, a skillful fighter, tried to negate Klitschko's strength with angles and head movement. Though he proved hard to hit, he failed to launch any sustained attack of his own. After the Johnson bout, Klitschko's camp began negotiations for a potential fight with former WBA Champion [[Nikolai Valuev]], but the match failed to materialize due to economic disagreements.{{cite web |last =Krikunov |first =Andrey |title =Vitali Klitschko-Nikolai Valuev Possible For April/May? |publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =28 December 2009 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=24364 |accessdate =9 May 2010}}{{cite web |last =Reeno |first =Rick |title =Vitali Klitschko, Nikolai Valuev Talks Have Cooled Down |publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =8 February 2010 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=25230 |accessdate =9 May 2010}}{{cite web |last =Krikunov |first =Andrey |title =Vitali Klitschko, Nikolai Valuev Hoping To Reach Terms |publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =2 March 2010 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=25718 |accessdate =9 May 2010}}{{cite web |last =Vester |first =Mark |title =Vitali Klitschko Says: "Nikolai Valuev is a Chicken" |publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =10 March 2010 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=25912 |accessdate =9 May 2010}} Christ, Scott. (19 February 2010) [http://www.badlefthook.com/2010/2/19/1317350/vitali-klitschko-will-retire-at Vitali Klitschko will retire at the end of 2010]. Bad Left Hook. Retrieved 19 April 2011. ===Klitschko vs. Sosnowski, Briggs, Solis=== On 29 May 2010, Vitali Klitschko defeated [[Poles|Polish]] heavyweight contender [[Albert Sosnowski]] by KO at 2:30 in round 10 of 12. Sosnowski was knocked down by a right hand in the 10th round, prompting referee Jay Nady to immediately wave off the fight. The fight took place at [[Veltins-Arena]], [[Gelsenkirchen]], [[Nordrhein-Westfalen]], Germany.[[File:Klitschko vs Sosnowski.JPG|left|thumb|Klitschko vs Sosnowski, 29 May 2010]] Vitali Klitschko weighed in at 112 kg (247 lbs), while Sosnowski weighed in at 110 kg (242.5 lbs). This voluntary defense was Vitali's 4th defense of the WBC Heavyweight title. Sosnowski was the No. 11 ranked heavyweight according to the WBC prior to this bout. {{cite web|url=http://boxrec.com/media/index.php?title=Fight:1500483|title=Vitali Klitschko vs. Albert Sosnowski|publisher=Boxrec.com|accessdate=27 November 2011}} On 17 August 2010, it was announced that Klitschko would defend his WBC title against [[Shannon Briggs]] on 16 October of that year. Klitschko completely dismantled his challenger with superior hand speed. Briggs struggled to land any meaningful punches, as Klitschko won every round decisively. After a few rounds, Briggs was receiving a vicious and sustained beating which caused him serious facial injuries. Considering the beating he was receiving, there was some suggestion that the referee should have stopped the bout during the last few rounds. Klitschko had retained his belt with official scores of 120–107, 120–105, and 120–107.{{cite web|last=Sukachev|first=Alexey|title=Vitali Klitschko Gives Briggs a Brutal Beating in Hamburg|publisher=BoxingScene.com|date=16 October 2010|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=31898|accessdate=5 December 2010}}{{cite news|title=Vitali Klitschko Keeps His Title|work=The New York Times|date=17 October 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/17/sports/17sportsbriefs-Wbc.html?_r=1&ref=vitaliklitschko|accessdate=8 January 2011}} During the post-fight interview, the American boxer Briggs said: "I've fought George Foreman, I've fought Lennox Lewis, and Vitali's the best." While Klitschko did not knock down Briggs, the latter collapsed after the fight and was hospitalized with facial fractures and a torn biceps. {{Main|Vitali Klitschko vs. Odlanier Solís}} Klitschko's next fight was against mandatory challenger [[Odlanier Solis]]. The [[Vitali Klitschko vs. Odlanier Solis|bout]] was tentatively scheduled for March 2011.{{cite web|last=Reeno|first=Rick|title=Klitschko-Solis Close, March 19 Eyed, Purse Bid Delayed|publisher=BoxingScene.com|date=7 January 2011|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=34487|accessdate=8 January 2011}} On 11 January, it was officially confirmed that the fight between Klitschko and Solis was going to take place in [[Cologne]], Germany on 19 March 2011. The fight lasted less than one whole round, as a right hand to Solis's temple wobbled Solis, who then twisted his knee. Klitschko won by KO.[http://www.klitschko.com/eng/Home.html Profile], Klitschko.com. Retrieved 19 April 2011.[http://www.klitschko.com/deu/Home.html Profile], Klitschko.com. Retrieved 19 April 2011.{{de icon}} ===Klitschko vs. Adamek, Chisora, Charr=== {{Main|Vitali Klitschko vs. Tomasz Adamek}} Now aged 40, Klitschko retained his WBC heavyweight title against [[Tomasz Adamek]] on 10 September 2011 in Poland, winning by TKO in the 10th round. The referee stopped the bout after Adamek received punishing blows and was ruled out, as he was no longer able to defend himself. After turning 41 on 19 July 2012, Vitali became one of the oldest Heavyweight Champions in history. Despite having a four-year hiatus from the sport, Vitali has proven to be a remarkably effective and dominant Heavyweight Champion once again. Alongside his brother Wladimir, he also fights on for their shared ambition of holding all four Heavyweight Championship belts together, an ambition that was realised on 2 July 2011 when brother Wladimir defeated [[David Haye]] to win the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Heavyweight Championship. In January 2012, he was awarded WBC Fighter of the Year for 2011.{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/sports/20120118/170829386.html|title=Klitschko Named WBC Fighter of 2011|date=18 January 2012|agency=RIA Novosti|accessdate=18 February 2012}} Klitschko was in negotiations for a possible bout with former WBA Heavyweight title holder David Haye on 3 March 2012.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/boxing/15927657.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Haye confirms Kiltschko fight talks|date=28 November 2011}}{{cite news| url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/boxing/3968197/David-Haye-could-fight-Vitali-Klitschko-in-March.html|location=London, UK|work=The Sun|first=Pat|last=Sheehan|title=David Haye could fight Vitali Klitschko in March}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxing/8924501/David-Haye-has-a-deal-on-the-table-to-go-ahead-and-fight-WBC-world-heavyweight-champion-Vitali-Klitschko-next-year.html|location=London, UK|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Gareth A.|last=Davies|title=David Haye has a deal on the table to go ahead and fight WBC world heavyweight champion Vitali Klitschko next year|date=30 November 2011}} [[File:VladimirVitaliy.jpg|thumb|Wladimir and Vitali with every title in the heavyweight division, 2012. Left to right: ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'', [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]], [[International Boxing Organization|IBO]], [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]], [[World Boxing Council|WBC]], and [[World Boxing Association|WBA]].]] After Wladimir Klitschko had to cancel his fight with [[Jean-Marc Mormeck]], it was thought that Vitali was likely to fight on 25 February 2012.[http://www.boxingscene.com/vitali-klitschko-vs-chisora-dimitrenko-haye-on-2-25--47011 Vitali Klitschko vs Chisora, Dimitrenko or Haye on 2/25?], Boxingscene.com, 8 December 2011. Retrieved 22 February 2012. Sources in Germany reported that he was likely to fight British contender [[Dereck Chisora]] on 18 February 2012 in [[Olympiahalle]], Munich, [[Bayern]].[http://www.boxingscene.com/klitschko-vs-chisora-on-february-18-then-haye-june--47186 Klitschko vs Chisora on February 18, Then Haye in June], Boxingscene.com, 13 December 2011. Retrieved 22 February 2012.[http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/7344389/vitali-klitschko-defend-wbc-title-dereck-chisora Vitali Klitschko to defend WBC title against Dereck Chisora – ESPN]. ESPN.go.com (12 December 2011). Retrieved 22 February 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/boxing/article-2073090/David-Hayes-fight-Vitali-Klitschko-threat-Ukranian-faces-Dereck-Chisora.html|location=London, UK|work=Daily Mail|title=Haye's comeback clash against Klitschko on hold as Vitali agrees Chisora date|date=12 December 2011}} {{Main|Vitali Klitschko vs. Dereck Chisora}} It was confirmed on 12 December 2011 that Dereck Chisora would be Vitali Klitschko's next opponent.[https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10150415777040205&set=a.325761250204.147701.285530825204&type=1 Prikbordfoto's]. Facebook.com' retrieved 22 February 2012.[http://www.rtl.de/cms/sport/boxen/news/naechster-vitali-fight-gegen-chisora-1cd68-302d-14-956960.html Chisora droht Klitschko: "Bin die schlimmste Pest"]. RTL.de (15 December 2011). Retrieved 22 February 2012. Vitali Klitschko retained his WBC Championship belt unanimously in a dominant display in Munich. The fight was fought against a backdrop of antagonism displayed by the contender Dereck Chisora at the weigh in. Chisora slapped Klitschko across the face causing a red mark to be left.[http://metro.co.uk/2012/02/17/dereck-chisora-slaps-vitali-klitschko-at-weigh-in-for-world-title-fight-323005 Dereck Chisora slaps Vitali Klitschko at weigh-in for world title fight], metro.co.uk (17 February 2012) The next day Chisora spat water over the face of Vitali's brother Wladimir.[http://www.badlefthook.com/2012/2/18/2808896/klitschko-vs-chisora-spit-face-wladimir-water-fight-results-boxing-video-news Klitschko vs Chisora: Dereck Chisora Spits in the Face of Wladimir Klitschko (Video)] badlefthook.com, 18 February 2012. Vitali won the majority of the rounds boxing a disciplined fight with changing angles and superior footwork. Chisora, constantly coming forward delivering punishing body shots, failed to wear down the older man. The scores were: 118–110, 118–110, and 119–111.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/boxing/17086859 Vitali Klitschko taken the distance by Dereck Chisora in Munich] BBC.co.uk (19 February 2012). The next day Vitali visited a hospital to check his shoulder, claiming he injured it in the fight. A doctor confirmed a ligament tear was suffered in his left shoulder. Klitschko said he "suddenly lost strength in the left hand" and was forced to only use his right. The injury was believed to have happened in the second or third round. Klitschko's trainer, Fritz Zdunek, believes this is the same kind of injury Vitali suffered in his fight with Byrd.[http://www.boxingscene.com/vitali-gets-medical-check-left-shoulder-injury-confirmed--49758 Vitali Gets Medical Check, Left Shoulder Injury Confirmed], Boxingscene.com. Retrieved 22 February 2012. At the post-fight press conference, a brawl ensued between Haye and Chisora. After the altercation, Chisora challenged Haye to a fight in the ring and said, "I am going to shoot David Haye." Chisora was later arrested at a German airport along with his coach, Don Charles. His comments and actions were later condemned by Frank Warren, his promoter, and Wladimir Klitschko. {{YouTube|Nkg1pK5n_FI|Dereck Chisora spits water on Wladimir Klitschko}}. Retrieved 22 February 2012.{{YouTube|lWrNGUeW2i8|Haye vs Chisora Fight Video from Munich Presser – Full video}} (18 February 2012). Retrieved 22 February 2012.{{YouTube|j5gMMeOz_dg|Dereck Chisora slaps Vitali Klitschko at Weigh In}}. Retrieved 22 February 2012.[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/feb/19/dereck-chisora-vitali-klitschko Dereck Chisora makes Vitali Klitschko fight to retain crown], ''The Guardian'', 19 February 2012. Retrieved 22 February 2012. On 2 July 2012, it was announced that Vitali Klitschko will defend his [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] [[Heavyweight]] title on 8 September at the [[Olympic Stadium (Moscow)|Olympic Indoor Arena]] in Moscow, Russia.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/more-sports/boxing/Vitali-Klitschko-lines-up-September-title-defence/articleshow/14612328.cms|title=Vitali Klitschko lines up September title defence|accessdate=2 July 2012|work=The Times of India}} His opponent for the fight was the then undefeated future WBA heavyweight champion [[Manuel Charr]] 21–0 (11 KO).[http://www.klitschko.com/en/home/news/article//moscow-to-st/ Moscow to stage first Klitschko World Heavyweight Championship in Russia: Official Website of Vitali & Wladimir Klitschko], Klitschko.com, 2 July 2012. Retrieved 10 July 2014. Klitschko won the fight via technical knockout when Charr had to be stopped due to a cut received from Vitali's punches.Sukachev, Alexey (8 September 2012) [http://www.boxingscene.com/vitali-klitschko-stops-bloody-manuel-charr-four--56869 Vitali Klitschko Stops a Bloody Manuel Charr in Four], Boxingscene.com. Retrieved 10 July 2014. Klitschko was expected to face [[Bermane Stiverne]] in a mandatory title defense, but was forced to pull out due to injury.{{cite news| title=Vitali Klitschko pulls out of mandatory WBC title defence against Bermane Stiverne|date=14 August 2013|url=http://www1.skysports.com/boxing/news/12183/8870089/vitali-klitschko-pulls-out-of-mandatory-wbc-title-defence-against-bermane-stiverne|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=28 December 2014}} ===Retirement from boxing=== On 15 December 2013, Vitali Klitschko stepped back from boxing. He was announced champion emeritus, which means that if he wants to return to boxing, he can fight the WBC Heavyweight Champion without having any fights beforehand. But (right after his retirement from boxing), Klitschko stated "That is something I currently cannot imagine".[https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/boxing/25409356 Vitali Klitschko: Heavyweight champion swaps boxing for politics], [[BBC Sport]] (67 December 2013) The WBC title was vacated and later contested by Chris Arreola and Bermane Stiverne.[http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/vitali-klitschko-becomes-wbc-champion-emeritus-233529 Boxing News | Vitali Klitschko becomes WBC champion emeritus, WBC heavyweight title now vacant] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216201900/http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/vitali-klitschko-becomes-wbc-champion-emeritus-233529 |date=16 December 2013 }}. Fightnews.com (16 December 2013). Retrieved 10 July 2014. Commenting on his decision, he stated "My focus is on [[politics in Ukraine]] and I feel the people there need me". He also added, "I thank the WBC and its president [[Jose Sulaiman]] for the support in our battle for democracy and freedom in Ukraine". Since his retirement, he has maintained a low key level of training and has been in his brother's corner for most fights, most famously when he had an altercation with [[Anthony Joshua]] after [[Anthony Joshua vs. Wladimir Klitschko]]. ==Political career (since 2005)== During the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] and the following [[Orange Revolution]], the [[Klitschko brothers]] openly supported the candidacy of [[Viktor Yushchenko]].{{ru icon}} [http://file.liga.net/person/229-vitalii-klichko.html Short bio], LIGA In 2005, (Vitali) Klitschko was appointed an adviser to [[President of Ukraine|President]] Yushchenko. In October 2006, he was promoted to full-time adviser. Klitschko began campaigning for [[Mayor of Kiev]] shortly after [[Vitali Klitschko#2005–2007 retirement|his retirement in 2005]]. He lost the 2006 mayoral election to [[Leonid Chernovetskyi]] but placed second with 26% of the vote, ahead of the incumbent [[Oleksandr Omelchenko]] Klitschko campaigned on an anti-corruption platform and lead the [[Political coalition|bloc]] "Civic party" PORA-ROP (the parties [[PORA#The political party|PORA]] and [[Reforms and Order Party]]) in the simultaneously held local elections for the [[Kyiv City Council]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2006/04/17/3095534/ Каськів вирішив, що Кличко одноразовий] by [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (17 April 2006) Analysts stated his relatively late entry into the campaign might have cost him votes. Still, Klitschko was elected as a people's deputy to the Kyiv City Council since "Civic party" PORA-ROP won 14 seats in the 2006 election.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/24142/ |title=Kyiv gets first new mayor in decade |work=Kyiv Post |date=29 March 2006 |accessdate=1 November 2009}} [[File:Martens meets Klitschko.jpg|thumb|left|Klitschko with [[Wilfried Martens]], former president of the [[European Peoples Party]].]] In the [[Kiev local election, 2008|May 2008 Kyiv local election]], he ran again and won 18% of the vote. Klitschko simultaneously led the [[Vitaliy Klychko Bloc]] that won 10.61% of the votes and 15 seats and again, he was elected into the Kyiv City Council.{{cite web|url=http://klichko.org/?C=53 |title=Biography Vitaliy Klitchko, official party website |publisher=Klichko.org |accessdate=1 November 2009}} His campaign hired [[Rudy Giuliani]] as a consultant for the campaign.{{cite news|last=Chan |first=Sewell |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/07/giuliani-weighs-in-on-race-for-mayor-in-ukraine/ |title=Giuliani Weighs in on Race for Mayor (in Ukraine) – City Room Blog |publisher=Cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com |date=7 May 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2009}} In 2008, he was also appointed to the Ukrainian delegation of the [[Congress of the Council of Europe]]. Klitschko became the leader of the political party [[Ukrainian Democratic Alliance for Reform]] (UDAR) in April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64928/ |title=WBC World Champion Vitaly Klitschko leads new party |work=Kyiv Post |date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=1 November 2009}} During the [[Ukrainian local elections, 2010|2010 Ukrainian local elections]], the party won representatives in (Ukrainian) municipalities and Oblast Councils (regional parliaments).{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/11/8/5552584/ Results of the elections, preliminary data, on interactive maps] by [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (8 November 2010){{uk icon}} [http://www.rada.cherkassy.ua/ua/newsread.php?view=1244&s=1&s1=17 Сергій Одарич формуватиме більшість у міськраді Черкас], [[Cherkasy]] city council website (8 November 2010){{uk icon}} [http://www.lvivnews.info/news/10338.html Мером Львова обрано Андрія Садового] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721222004/http://www.lvivnews.info/news/10338.html |date=21 July 2011 }}, [[ЛьвівNEWS]] (November 2010) Klitscho and UDAR became a partner of the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] of Germany in November 2011.{{de icon}} [http://www.cdu-kreis-dueren.de/2011/11/15/24-cdu-bundesparteitag-in-leipzig/ 24. CDU-Bundesparteitag in Leipzig], [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] branch [[Düren]]-[[Jülich]] (15 November 2011)
{{de icon}} [http://www.lvz-online.de/nachrichten/cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig/politik-ist-wie-ein-boxkampf-vitali-klitschko-beim-cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig-im-exklusiv-interview/r-cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig-a-113528.html „Politik ist wie ein Boxkampf“: Vitali Klitschko beim CDU-Parteitag in Leipzig im Interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121210120234/http://www.lvz-online.de/nachrichten/cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig/politik-ist-wie-ein-boxkampf-vitali-klitschko-beim-cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig-im-exklusiv-interview/r-cdu-parteitag-in-leipzig-a-113528.html |date=10 December 2012 }}, [[Leipziger Volkszeitung]] (14 November 2011) UDAR is supported by the German government and the [[Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung|Konrad Adenauer Foundation]][http://www.kas.de/wf/de/33.21719/ article about UDAR on the website of the foundation]. Kas.de. Retrieved on 2015-11-29.{{cite web |url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/aussenpolitik/1306144/Wahlen-in-der-Ukraine_Klitschkos-schwierigster-Kampf |title=Wahlen in der Ukraine: Klitschkos schwierigster Kampf |work=[[Die Presse]] |author=Jutta Sommerbauer |date=27 October 2012 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} and received support in particular from [[Angela Merkel]] and also politicians from the conservative [[European People's Party]]. According to information gained by the German magazine ''Der Spiegel'', the target was to "set up Klitschko purposefully as a new strong man in Kiev – in order to counter this way the Kremlin's growing influence". Support consisted in logistics, training and joint performances. Assistance was also promised by [[Christoph Heusgen]], [[Ronald Pofalla]] and [[Guido Westerwelle]].[http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/ukraine-merkel-will-klitschko-zum-praesidenten-aufbauen-a-937853.html Merkel kämpft für Klitschko], SPON 8. Dezember 2013 [[File:Deputy Secretary Burns Meets With Key Ukrainian Political Leaders (12772352205).jpg|thumb|Klitschko, [[Petro Poroshenko|Poroshenko]], [[Oleh Tyahnybok|Tyahnybok]] and [[United States Deputy Secretary of State|U.S. Deputy Secretary of State]] [[William Joseph Burns|William Burns]], 25 February 2014]] In October 2011, Klitschko announced that he would run in the 2012 Kiev mayoral election.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2011/10/22/6695550/ Кличко збирається в мери і в парламент], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (22 October 2011) During the [[2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], Klitschko was elected (he was top candidate on UDAR's party list) into the [[Ukrainian parliament]]; when his party won 40 seats. Klitschko was chosen the leader of the party's faction in Parliament.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/udar-elects-factions-leadership-in-parliament-317537.html UDAR elects faction's leadership in parliament], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (12 December 2012) Klitschko announced on 24 October 2013 that he intended to take part in the [[2014 Ukrainian presidential election|next Ukrainian presidential election that was then set for 2015]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/171819.html Vitali Klitschko says intends to run for president in Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 October 2013)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/171794.html Parliament passes law that could prevent Klitschko from running for president], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 October 2013){{#tag:ref|In December 2013, he stated "My plans have no changed. I made a decision [...] I will run for president of Ukraine[http://interfax.com.ua/news/political/183714.html Кличко подтверждает намерение баллотироваться в президенты]. Interfax.com.ua (24 December 2013). Retrieved 10 July 2014.|group=nb}} Experts and lawyers then argued that it was unclear if Klitschko could take part in these elections. Under Ukrainian law, a presidential candidate must have had his residence in Ukraine for the past ten years prior to election day; and Klitschko had lived for many years in Ukraine and Germany, where, according to media reports, he has a residence permit. Opinion polls since early 2011 showed that the predicted percentage of votes that Klitschko would gain in the first round of the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election enlarged from 4.8% in December 2011 to 15.1% in February 2013, and an October 2013 [[Razumkov Centre]] poll predicted 19.3%.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/every-fourth-ukrainian-ready-to-vote-for-yanukovych-in-presidential-election-poll-2/ Every fourth Ukrainian ready to vote for Yanukovych in presidential election – poll], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 March 2013)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/survey-yanukovych-and-tymoshenko-would-compete-for-presidency-in-early-presidential-elections/ Survey: Yanukovych and Tymoshenko would compete for presidency in early presidential elections], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 December 2012)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/poll-yanukovych-leads-tymoshenko-in-presidential-rankings-by-small-margin/ Poll: Yanukovych leads Tymoshenko in presidential rankings by small margin], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (5 December 2011)
[https://archive.is/20130420221208/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/tymoshenko-leads-presidential-rating-%E2%80%93-poll-2/ Tymoshenko leads presidential rating – poll], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (27 December 2011)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/poll-yanukovych-has-highest-presidential-rating/ Poll: Yanukovych has highest ‘presidential’ rating], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 February 2011){{#tag:ref|Since February 2013 polls predict that Klitschko will win the second round of the 2015 presidential election against incumbent President [[Viktor Yanukovych]].[http://www.ratinggroup.com.ua/en/products/politic/data/entry/14049/ Ratings of politicians in presidential elections: February 2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006080826/http://www.ratinggroup.com.ua/en/products/politic/data/entry/14049/ |date=6 October 2013 }}, [[Sociological group "RATING"]] (6 March 2013){{uk icon}} [http://www.kiis.com.ua/?lang=ukr&cat=reports&id=173&page=1 ЕЛЕКТОРАЛЬНІ НАМІРИ ВИБОРЦІВ УКРАЇНИ НАПРИКІНЦІ ТРАВНЯ], [[Kyiv International Institute of Sociology|KIIS]] (30 May 2013)
{{uk icon}} [http://rb.com.ua/rus/projects/omnibus/8827/ Электоральные предпочтения украинцев в начале нового политического сезона], [[Research & Branding Group|R&B Group]] (25 September 2013)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.razumkov.org.ua/upload/Press1013.pdf Електоральні орієнтації громадян України та ставлення до провідних політиків], [[Razumkov Centre]] (14 October 2013)|group=nb}} [[File:Rada Krajowa Platformy Obywatelskiej RP (22 marca 2014) (13327934843).jpg|thumb|left|Klitschko with Polish politicians [[Donald Tusk]] and [[Ewa Kopacz]], 22 March 2014]] Klitschko was one of the dominant figures of the [[Euromaidan]] protests. During these protests, he retired from boxing. He confirmed on 28 February 2014 that he would take part in the (early) [[2014 Ukrainian presidential election]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/193451.html Klitschko confirms he, Tymoshenko will run for president], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 February 2014){{#tag:ref|Amidst the [[Euromaidan]] protests and on 11 December 2013, in a confidential hacked conversation, [[US Assistant Secretary of State]] [[Victoria Nuland]] told the [[United States Ambassador to Ukraine]] [[Geoffrey R. Pyatt]], "I don't think 'Klitsch' should go into the government... I don't think it's a good idea. I think [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk|'Yats']] is the guy who's got the economic experience, the governing experience. He ... needs 'Klitsch' and [[Oleh Tyahnybok|Tyahnybok]] on the outside... talking to them four times a week."[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26079957 BBC News – Ukraine crisis: Transcript of leaked Nuland-Pyatt call]. BBC.com (7 February 2014). Retrieved 13 January 2015.|group=nb}} But on 29 March 2014 announced that he had changed his mind and would run for the post of [[Mayor of Kiev]] in the [[Kiev local election, 2014|2014 Kiev local election]] (including Mayoral elections) set for 25 May 2014.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192688.html Parliament sets elections for Kyiv mayor and Kyiv City Council deputies for May 25], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 February 2014)[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198350.html Klitschko will run for mayor of Kyiv], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (29 March 2014) In the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election Klitschko endorsed the candidacy of [[Petro Poroshenko]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198348.html Klitschko believes only presidential candidate from democratic forces should be Poroshenko], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (29 March 2014) Klitschko won Kiev's mayoral elections with almost 57% of the votes.[http://www.straitstimes.com/news/world/europe/story/ukraine-boxing-hero-klitschko-claims-kyiv-mayor-seat-20140526/ Ukraine boxing hero Klitschko claims Kyiv mayor seat], ''[[The Straits Times]]'' (26 May 2014) He was sworn in as mayor on 5 June 2014. The same day the Ukrainian parliament had deprived Klitschko of his MP mandate (Ukrainian MPs are not entitled to combine parliamentary activities with any other public employment).[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/klitschko_becomes_kyiv_mayor_officially_322448 Klitschko becomes Kyiv Mayor officially], [[Ukrinform]] (5 June 2014)
[http://www.novostimira.com.ua/news-eng-110753.html Klitschko was deprived of parliamentary mandate], [[NovostiMira]] (5 June 2014) Poroshenko was elected [[President of Ukraine]] on 25 May 2014. Poroshenko appointed Klitschko as head of [[Kiev City State Administration]] on 25 June 2014.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/210904.html Poroshenko appoints Klitschko head of Kyiv city administration – decree], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 June 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/210980.html Poroshenko orders Klitschko to bring title of best European capital back to Kyiv], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 June 2014) Klitschko headed the election list of the [[Petro Poroshenko Bloc "Solidarity"|Petro Poroshenko Bloc]] in the late October [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], but he vowed not to resign as Mayor of Kiev.{{ru icon}} [http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/politics/3418992-letchyky-kombaty-zhurnalysty-kto-ydet-v-novuui-verkhovnuui-radu Pilots, combat, and journalists. Who goes to the new Verkhovna Rada ], [[Korrespondent.net]] (September 15, 2014)
[http://klichko.org/news/?id=23180&lang=eng Klitschko: I lead my team to Parliament], [[UDAR]] official website (14.09.2014)
[http://en.itar-tass.com/world/749643 Deadline for nomination of candidates running in early election to Rada expires], [[ITAR-TASS]] (September 15, 2014)
{{cite web|url=http://112.ua/statji/spisok-deputatov-prohodyaschih-v-radu-po-spiskam-i-mazhoritarke-predvaritelnye-dannye-137800.html|publisher=112.ua|title=Список депутатов, проходящих в Раду по спискам и мажоритарке, – предварительные данные}} On 21 November 2014 Klitschko gave up his seat in the new parliament.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/235662.html Klitschko gives up seat in parliament], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 November 2014) Petro Poroshenko Bloc won the election with 132 seats.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/poroshenko-and-yatsenyuks-parties-maneuver-for-lead-role-in-coalition-369983.html Poroshenko and Yatsenyuk’s parties maneuver for lead role in coalition ], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2014)
[https://www.kyivpost.com/opinion/editorial/new-verkhovna-rada-370121.html New Verkhovna Rada], [[Kyiv Post]] (Oct. 30, 2014)[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/poroshenko_bloc_to_have_greatest_number_of_seats_in_parliament_327072 Poroshenko Bloc to have greatest number of seats in parliament], [[Ukrinform]] (8 November 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233404.html People's Front 0.33% ahead of Poroshenko Bloc with all ballots counted in Ukraine elections – CEC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112013057/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233404.html |date=12 November 2014 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 November 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233426.html Poroshenko Bloc to get 132 seats in parliament – CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 November 2014) On 28 August 2015 the UDAR merged into [[Petro Poroshenko Bloc "Solidarity"]]. Klitschko became the new party leader. In the [[Ukrainian local elections, 2015#Kiev|2015 Kiev Mayoral election]] Klitschko was reelected with 66.5% of vote. For this he needed a second round of Mayoral elections between him and [[Boryslav Bereza]] after incumbent Klitschko scored 40.5% of the vote and Bereza 8.8% in the first round.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/298832.html Klitschko undisputed leader in elections for Kyiv mayor, while second round possible – Savik Shuster Studio exit poll]. En.interfax.com.ua (2015-10-25). Retrieved on 2015-11-29.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/300458.html With 100% of ballots counted, Klitschko, Bereza to stand in Kyiv mayoral election runoff]. En.interfax.com.ua (2015-10-30). Retrieved on 2015-11-29.[http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-politics/1906527-klitschko-mp-bereza-enters-2nd-round-of-kyiv-mayor-election.html Klitschko, MP Bereza enter 2nd round of Kyiv mayor election — Ukrinform News]. Ukrinform.net (2015-10-30). Retrieved on 2015-11-29. (Bereza gained 33.51% of the vote in the second round of Mayoral elections.) Klitschko resigned as Petro Poroshenko Bloc chairman (on 26 May) after a new law barring a head of administration to be chairman or a member of a political party took effect on 1 May 2016. ===Political positions=== Klitschko is in favor of the [[EU-Ukraine relations#European Union Association Agreement|Association Agreement]] between Ukraine and the [[European Union]].[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/klitschko-says-he-responsibly-considers-possibility-of-running-for-president/ Klitschko says he responsibly considers possibility of running for president], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 August 2013)[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/klitschko-ukraines-eu-prospects-depend-on-new-parliament-317148.html Klitschko, Merkel discuss prospects for signing EU-Ukraine association agreement], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (5 December 2012) He sees the European Union as Ukraine's "model for [Ukraine's] future political and economic development."{{cite web |url=http://klichko.org/en/news/publications/miy-noviy-biy-za-krayinu-yevropeyskogo-zrazka-kolonka-vitaliya-klichko-u-the-times |title=My new fight is for a country more like Europe |author=Vitali Klitschko |work=The Times |date=22 November 2011}} He believes former [[Ukrainian President|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and his [[First Azarov government|government]] were "deliberately destroying the [[Ukraine–European Union relations|integration (into Europe) prospects of Ukraine]]" and that Ukrainian politicians have no right to let them "rule after [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014]]". Klitschko is also in favour of [[Ukraine–NATO relations|NATO-Ukraine cooperation]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2011/11/26/6787507/ Кличко закликає активніше говорити про НАТО], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (26 November 2011) [[File:Euroaidan 2013 Mstyslav Chernov-9.jpg|thumb|Vitali, leader of the political party UDAR seen in the crowd on [[Khreschatyk]] street in Kiev, Ukraine on 27 November 2013.]] Klitschko's main concern is social standards and the [[economy of Ukraine]].[http://ukrainianweek.com/Politics/83976 In Pursuit of the Presidency], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (8 July 2013) He believes "[[Russian language in Ukraine#Russian language in Ukrainian politics|the issue of language]] is not the top priority". Klitschko wants less [[corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] and more transparency in Ukrainian politics. He also advocates lower taxes to stimulate the economy. Klitschko did accuse in October 2011 President Yanukovych and the Azarov Government of "doing everything to manipulate the rules to stay in power longer";[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114606/ Klitschko meets with McCain to discuss deterioration of democracy in Ukraine], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (12 October 2011) furthermore (in December 2011) he assert(ed) "every statement of the government" as "a continuation of lies and disinformation."{{uk icon}} [http://www.unian.net/ukr/news/news-477480.html Кличко зрозумів, що Янукович зневажає історію], [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency]] (30 December 2011) He has also taken part in rallies for former Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]'s release.{{#tag:ref|Klitschko wanted former Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] and former [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ukraine)|Interior Minister]] [[Yuriy Lutsenko]] to be able to participate in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] (Lutsenko has been charged with [[abuse of power]] and Tymoshenko has been sentenced on the same charge).[https://archive.is/20130223053740/http://main.omanobserver.om/node/80452 Thousands rally for Ukraine ex-PM’s release], [[Oman Daily Observer]] (23 January 2012)[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/92402/ Tymoshenko, Lutsenko should participate in 2012 parliamentary elections, says Klychko], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (23 January 2012) Tymoshenko was released on 22 February 2014, in the concluding days of the "[[2014 Ukrainian revolution|Maidan revolution]]", following a revision of the Ukrainian criminal code that effectively decriminalized the actions for which she was imprisoned and officially rehabilitated on 28 February 2014.[http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_03_03/Ukraines-ex-Prime-Minister-Yulia-Tymoshenko-officially-rehabilitated-3865/ Ukraine's ex-Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko officially rehabilitated – News – World – The Voice of Russia: News, Breaking news, Politics, Economics, Business, Russia, International current events, Expert opinion, podcasts, Video]. The Voice of Russia. Retrieved 10 July 2014.{{cite news|title=Embattled Ukraine President Signs Compromise Deal as Parliament Votes to Free His Imprisoned Rival|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/22/world/europe/ukraine.html?emc=edit_na_20140221&_r=0|accessdate=21 February 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 February 2014|author=Andrew Higgins|author2=Andrew Cramer}}[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26312008 Ukraine: Speaker Oleksandr Turchynov named interim president], [[BBC News]] (23 February 2014)
[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 Ukraine protests timeline], [[BBC News]] (23 February 2014){{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ukraine-crisis/ally-opposition-icon-tymoshenko-voted-acting-ukraine-president-n36531|title=Ally of Opposition Icon Tymoshenko Voted Acting Ukraine President|publisher=NBC News|date=23 February 2014|accessdate=25 February 2014}} Lutsenko was on 7 April 2013 released from prison because [[Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] had pardoned him (among others) for health reasons.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22061269 Ukraine President Viktor Yanukovych pardons Yulia Tymoshenko allies], [[BBC News]] (8 April 2013)
[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22057073 Ukrainian leader Yanukovych pardons Tymoshenko ally], [[BBC News]] (7 April 2013)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/ukrainian-president-pardons-lutsenko-and-filipchuk-decree-3/ Ukrainian president pardons Lutsenko and Filipchuk – decree], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (7 April 2013) |group=nb}} In December 2011 Klitschko described the [[judicial system of Ukraine]] as "complete degradation" and accused it of violating [[human rights in Ukraine|human rights]] and humiliating its [[Prisons in Ukraine|prisoners]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/118464/ Klitschko: Holding court on Tymoshenko in cell shows degradation of judicial system in Ukraine], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (8 December 2011) According to him Ukraine lacks independent and unbiased judges because "The Ukrainian judiciary is currently a closed clan; lifelong judges and appointments through administrative leverage". He wants to ensure the independence of judges by switching from a system of appointed judges to a system of elected judges. In July 2012 party-leader Klitschko stated his party UDAR will not cooperate with the [[Party of Regions]] in the [[Ukrainian Parliament]].{{uk icon}} [http://tyzhden.ua/News/55692 Кличко каже, що не співпрацюватиме в парламенті з Партією регіонів ''Klitschko says he does not cooperate in Parliament with the Party of Regions''], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (18 July 2012) In early April 2013 Klitschko called for early [[Presidential elections in Ukraine|presidential]] and [[Parliamentary elections in Ukraine|parliamentary elections]] in Ukraine.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/klitschko-calls-for-early-presidential-parliamentary-elections-in-ukraine-2/ Klitschko calls for early presidential, parliamentary elections in Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 April 2013) Klitschko is a member of the [[International Republican Institute]]'s International Advisory Council.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iri.org/who-we-are/international-advisory-council|title=International Advisory Council {{!}} IRI|website=www.iri.org|access-date=2017-05-03}} == Personal life == [[File:Klitschko brothers 2010 Ukraine stamp.jpg|thumb|Klitschko brothers on a 2010 Ukrainian stamp]] Klitschko's father, Vladimir Rodionovich Klitschko (1947–2011), was a [[Soviet Air Force]] [[major general]] and a Soviet [[military attaché]] in East Germany. The elder Klitschko was also one of the commanders in charge of cleaning up the effects of the [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster]] in 1986 and was afterward diagnosed with cancer.[http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/6769684/vladimir-rodionovich-klitschko-dies-father-wladimir-vitali-klitschko Vladimir Rodionovich Klitschko dies; father of Wladimir and Vitali Klitschko – ESPN]. ESPN.go.com (14 July 2011). Retrieved 10 July 2014. His mother is Nadezhda Ulyanovna.[http://kp.ua/daily/130711/290155/ У братьев Кличко умер отец] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124003705/http://kp.ua/daily/130711/290155 |date=24 November 2011 }}. Komsomolskaya Pravda (in Russian) 13 July 2011 Klitschko has been accused of working as a debt collector in the 1990s for [[Boss (crime)|mafia boss]] Viktor Rybalko.[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/boxer-vitali-klitschko-campaigns-for-seat-in-ukraine-parliament-a-841647.html A Fight without Rules: Boxer Vitali Klitschko Enters Ukraine's Political Arena], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (29 June 2012){{#tag:ref|After 25 December 2013 attack on [[Tetiana Chornovol]] police investigator Mykola Chynchyn stated that one of the suspects in this case used to be in a criminal organization led by Viktor Rybalko; and added "[[The Klitschko brothers]] allegedly were closely involved in Rybalko's organization".|group=nb}} Klitschko has vehemently denied links to Rybalko.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/police-implicate-link-klitschko-brothers-other-opposition-members-to-chornovol-beating-suspects-334343.html Police implicate, link Klitschko brothers, other opposition members to Chornovol beating suspects (UPDATE)], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (27 December 2013)[http://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/iryna-solomko/ukraine%E2%80%99s-point-of-no-return Ukraine’s point of no return], [[openDemocracy.net]] (29 December 2013) Vitali Klitschko is married to Natalia Egorova, a former athlete and model. They met in Kiev and got married on 26 April 1996. He has three children, Yegor-Daniel, Elizabeth-Victoria and Max (named after the former World Heavyweight Champion [[Max Schmeling]]).[http://sport.segodnya.ua/boxing/818925.html Кличко улетел от жены, как 14 лет назад] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401181242/http://sport.segodnya.ua/boxing/818925.html |date=1 April 2012 }}. Segondnya (in Russian). 26 April 2010[http://men.org.ua/rus/?action=celeb&cid=65 Виталий Кличко] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425083842/http://men.org.ua/rus/?action=celeb&cid=65 |date=25 April 2012 }}. men.org.ua [[File:Klitschko Kramnik 2002 Dortmund.jpg|thumb|left|Vitali Klitschko (left) playing chess with [[Vladimir Kramnik]], Dortmund, 2002.]] In 1996, Klitschko graduated from the Pereyaslav-Khmelnytsky Pedagogical Institute (Ukraine) and was accepted into the postgraduate study program at the [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv]]. On 29 February 2000, he presented his doctoral thesis on "talent and sponsorship in sports"[http://cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/fw32002.htm CyberBoxingZone News, 29-02-2000 "Calling Dr. Klitschko"]. Retrieved 7 November 2008. at the "Kyiv University of Physical Science and Sports" and his PhD in Sports Science was conferred. Klitschko has lived for years in Germany (in addition to residing in [[Kiev]]). According to Klitschko "Germany adopted me, I really love Germany, but I'm not German". Both Vitali and his brother are avid [[chess]] players. Vitali is a friend of former world chess champion [[Vladimir Kramnik]] and the two have played, with Kramnik always winning. Vitali has commented that "chess is similar to boxing. You need to develop a strategy, and you need to think two or three steps ahead about what your opponent is doing. You have to be smart. But what's the difference between chess and boxing? In chess, nobody is an expert, but everybody plays. In boxing everybody is an expert, but nobody fights."{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.hbo.com/boxing/fighters/klitschko_vitali/bio.html|title=Boxing: Fighters: Bio: VITALI KLITSCHKO|publisher=HBO.com|date=27 September 2009|accessdate=1 November 2009}} Vitali and his brother also have been involved in charitable activities dedicated to supporting the needs of schools, churches and children. In 2002, the Klitschko brothers announced that they had agreed to work for [[UNESCO]]. {{citation needed|date=January 2015}} Vitali and his brother never fought each other in a professional fight as their mother made them promise to never fight each other .{{cite web|author=Gary Morley and Matt Vigil|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/08/sport/wladimir-klitschko-boxing-ukraine/|title=Wladimir Klitschko: Iron Curtain no barrier for 'Dr. Steelhammer'|publisher=CNN.com|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=4 Januari 2017}} ==Awards== * In 2010, Klitschko was awarded the German [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Cross of the Order of Merit]] for his social and political engagement.{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/sport/boxen/boxen-bundesverdienstkreuz-an-klitschko-ueberreicht_aid_515659.html|title=Bundesverdienstkreuz an Klitschko überreicht|publisher=Focus|date=4 June 2010}} * In 2016, Klitschko was named The Eternal World Heavyweight Champion by the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]]; the title is awarded to dominant boxers that were undefeated as champions and had plenty of successful title defenses throughout their careers{{cite web|url=http://www.boxingnewsonline.net/vitali-klitschko-named-eternal-world-heavyweight-champion-by-the-wbc|title= Vitali Klitschko named
