{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:winifred-emery-1896.jpg|thumb|right|Winifred Emery in 1896]] '''Winifred Emery''' (1 August 1861 – 15 July 1924), born '''Maud Isabel Emery''', was an English actress and [[actor-manager]] of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. She was the wife of the actor [[Cyril Maude]].
Born into a family of actors, Emery began acting as a child. Her career grew through the 1880s and 1890s as she played leading roles in the [[West End theatre|West End]] of London. After a period away from the stage, she returned with leading roles in the company of [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]]. She continued to act steadily in her own touring theatre company with her husband and in London theatres until 1922.
==Early life and career== Emery was born in [[Manchester]], Lancashire, the daughter of [[Samuel Anderson Emery]] and granddaughter of John Emery, both well-known actors in their day. Her first stage appearance was in 1870, aged 8, in [[J. B. Buckstone]]'s ''The Green Bushes'' at the Alexandra Theatre in [[Liverpool]]. Her first London appearance was on 23 December 1874 when she played Happy New Year in the [[pantomime]] ''[[Beauty and the Beast]]'' at the [[Princess's Theatre, London|Princess's Theatre]]. In 1879 she joined [[Marie Litton]]'s company before appearing with [[Wilson Barrett]] at the [[Grand Theatre, Leeds|Grand Theatre]] in [[Leeds]]. She moved with Barrett to the [[Royal Court Theatre|Court Theatre]] in London in October 1879.<ref name=ODNB>C. M. P. Taylor, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/49696 Emery, Winifred (1861–1924)], ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online ed., January 2008, accessed 7 June 2011</ref> There she was first noticed by the critics when she appeared in the one-act play ''A Clerical Error''.<ref>Interview in ''The Sketch'', 7 December 1911</ref>
Emery appeared in ''A Bridal Tour'' at the [[Haymarket Theatre]] in August 1880, and performed at the [[St James's Theatre]] with Sir [[John Hare (actor)|John Hare]], [[William Hunter Kendal]] and [[Madge Kendal]]. In July 1881 she joined the company of [[Henry Irving]] at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]], and there she appeared in ''[[The Bells (play)|The Bells]]'' and ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]''. She later played at [[Folly Theatre|Toole's Theatre]] and at the [[Vaudeville Theatre]] with [[Thomas Thorne]] in ''[[The Rivals]]''. In 1884 she became the understudy for [[Ellen Terry]] at the Lyceum Theatre and toured the United States with Henry Irving, playing in ''[[Twelfth Night]]'', ''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'' and ''The Merchant of Venice''. Also for Irving, in October 1885 Emery played the title role in ''[[Olivia (play)|Olivia]]'' by [[William Gorman Wills|W. G. Wills]], and toured the United States again in 1887–8.<ref name=ODNB/>
Emery married the actor [[Cyril Maude]] on 28 April 1888 at [[Kensington]] Register Office, and they had another marriage ceremony at the [[Savoy Chapel]] on 2 June 1888. She next appeared at the Vaudeville Theatre and, for [[Augustus Harris]], at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]]. Returning to the Vaudeville Theatre in February 1890, she played the title role in ''[[Clarissa]]'', adapted by [[Robert Williams Buchanan]] from the novel by [[Samuel Richardson]].<ref>''Clarissa'', ''[[The Times]]'', 7 February 1890</ref> In the same year, and at the same theatre, she played leading roles in ''[[The School for Scandal]]'' and ''[[She Stoops to Conquer]]'', among others.<ref name=ODNB/> She starred in ''Judah'' by [[Henry Arthur Jones]] at the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] in September 1890 before appearing at the Olympic Theatre with [[Wilson Barrett]] in December 1890.
May 1891 saw Emery back at the Shaftesbury Theatre, and in February 1892 she took the title role in the original production of [[Oscar Wilde]]'s ''[[Lady Windermere's Fan]]'' at the [[St James's Theatre]]. Between 1893 and 1895 Emery played the lead female roles for [[J. Comyns Carr]] at the [[Comedy Theatre]], where she appeared in [[Sydney Grundy|Grundy's]] ''The New Woman'' and ''Sowing the Wind'' and [[Arthur Wing Pinero|Pinero]]'s ''The Benefit of the Doubt''. Such was her fame by this time that her portrait was drawn by [[Aubrey Beardsley]], appearing in the January 1895 edition of ''[[The Yellow Book]]''.<ref>[http://www.collectorspost.com/emery.htm Winifred Emery], Collector's Post website, accessed 7 June 2011</ref> In February 1896 she appeared at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]] under the management of Sir [[Johnston Forbes-Robertson]].<ref name=ODNB/>
==Later years== [[File:winifred-emery-1901.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Emery with her children, c. 1901]] In 1896 her husband became [[actor-manager]] of the [[Haymarket Theatre]], and Emery went with him, becoming his leading lady. However, owing to a period of illness and the birth of her son, she made just one appearance there between 1898 and 1905, in ''The Second in Command'', by Robert Marshall, in July 1901. She made her theatrical 'comeback' in February 1905, when she played Beatrice in ''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'' opposite [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]]. In January 1906 she appeared at the [[Novello Theatre|Waldorf Theatre]] as Mrs Pellender in ''The Superior Miss Pellender''. Emery formed her own theatrical company and with it she and her husband toured provincial theatres, the two of them starring in ''Olivia and Her Son'' by [[Horace Annesley Vachell]]. This play transferred to the [[Playhouse Theatre]], then under Cyril Maude's management, in March 1907.<ref name=ODNB/>
From 1907 to 1922 Emery played leading roles in numerous productions at West End theatres, including the Playhouse Theatre with her husband; His Majesty's Theatre in ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]''; Drury Lane in ''The Bunking of Betty''; the St James's Theatre in [[Thomas William Robertson|T. W. Robertson's]] ''[[Caste (play)|Caste]]''; the [[Lyric Theatre, London|Lyric Theatre]] in ''Sir Walter Ralegh''; the [[Vaudeville Theatre]] in Pinero's ''The Schoolmistress''; the [[Apollo Theatre]] in ''Never Say Die'' by W. H. Post, starring [[Charles Hawtrey (stage actor)|Charles Hawtrey]] (1913); the [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]] in [[Maurice Maeterlinck|Maeterlinck's]] ''The Betrothal'', and at the [[Duke of York's Theatre]] in Pinero's ''The Enchanted Cottage'' (1922). At the [[Royal Command Performance]] in May 1911 at Drury Lane before [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]], Emery appeared in an excerpt from [[Edward Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton|Bulwer-Lytton's]] ''Money''; and at the Coronation Gala Performance for [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]], held at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]] on 27 June 1911, she played [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] in [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan|Sheridan]]'s ''[[The Critic (play)|The Critic]]'', directed by Sir [[Squire Bancroft]].<ref name=ODNB/> Her last performance was at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]] on 26 February 1923 in a charity production of ''The Ballad Monger''.
Emery died of stomach cancer at her home in [[Bexhill-on-Sea]] in Sussex, aged 62, and was buried at St Mark's Church in Bexhill.
==Family life== Her children with Maude included [[Margery Maude]], who became an actress; Pamela Cynthia Maude (1893–1975); and [[John Cyril Maude]], who became a barrister, judge and Member of Parliament.<ref>[http://thepeerage.com/p5788.htm The family of Winifred Emery] on thepeerage.com, accessed 8 June 2011</ref> Pamela Maude married Major [[Billy Congreve|William La Touche Congreve]] [[Victoria Cross|VC]], [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Military Cross|MC]] on 1 June 1916. He was killed in action on 20 July 1916 during [[World War I]], for which he was posthumously awarded the [[Victoria Cross]].<ref>[http://www.wakefieldfhs.org.uk/genealogyjunction/Eton/Eton%20Roll%20of%20Honour%20Latin%20text.html Eton College – Rolls of Honour], accessed 8 June 2011</ref> On 22 December 1919 she married Captain [[Brigadier the Hon. William Fraser|William Fraser]], [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Military Cross|MC]] (1890–1964), who eventually rose to the rank of [[Brigadier (United Kingdom)|Brigadier]].<ref>[http://www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/index340.htm Lord Saltoun of Abernethy] on cracroftpeerage.co.uk, accessed 8 June 2011</ref>
Emery brought up her niece, Winifred Isabel Emery (1890–1972),<ref name=Gas>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/76473?docPos=1 Gascoyne, David], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', accessed 2 June 2011</ref><ref name=Dark>[[Sidney Dark|Dark, Sidney]] and Rowland Grey. ''W. S. Gilbert: His Life and Letters'', Methuen & Co Ltd, London (1923), pp. 222–223</ref> after the girl was abandoned by Emery's brother in 1895. This niece, together with her pupil [[Patricia Preece|Ruby Preece]], was present when dramatist [[W. S. Gilbert]] died in his lake at [[Grim's Dyke]] in May 1911.<ref>Goodman, Andrew. ''Grim's Dyke: A Short History of the House and Its Owners'', Glittering Prizes {{ISBN|978-1-85811-550-4}}, pp. 17–18</ref> Winifred Isabel Emery was the mother of poet [[David Gascoyne]].<ref name=Gas/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchresult.cfm?parent_id=514269&word= Winifred Emery Emery] on [[New York Public Library]]'s Digital Gallery *[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp58018/winifred-emery-maud-isabel-emery-later-maud-isabel-maude?search=sas&sText=winifred+emery Photographs of Emery] on the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] website *[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O85079/painting-winifred-emery-as-rosamund-cyril/ Painting] by [[Walter Sickert]] of Emery, [[Cyril Maude]] and [[Brandon Thomas]] in ''Sowing the Wind'' by [[Sydney Grundy]] – [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] website
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Emery, Winifred}} [[Category:1861 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:English stage actresses]] [[Category:Actresses from Manchester]] [[Category:Actor-managers]] [[Category:People associated with Gilbert and Sullivan]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Zou Rong | image = Zou Rong Portrait.png | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1885 | birth_place = | death_date = 1905 | death_place = | nationality = Chinese | other_names = | known_for = Writing ''The Revolutionary Army'' | occupation = }} {{Chinese name|[[Zou (surname)|Zou]]}} '''Zou Rong''' ({{zh|t=鄒容|p=Zōu Róng|w=Tsou Jung}}; 1885 – 1905) was a Chinese nationalist, racialist and revolutionary martyr of the anti-Qing movement. He was born in [[Chongqing]], [[Sichuan]] Province, his ancestors having moved there from [[Meizhou]], Guangdong area.<ref>{{cite web | title = 泸州老窖的客家故事之二 迁川往事：忘不了的根，磨不灭的志| url=http://zwgk.gd.gov.cn/007208023/201306/t20130604_377035.html}}</ref> Zou was sent to [[Japan]] at an early age, where he studied the successful Japanese way of modernization.
When he returned to China, he started to write essays on how to free the Chinese nation from the Manchu regime and foreign imperialism. In 1903, he published a book on this topic: ''The Revolutionary Army'' (''geming jun'' 革命軍). The deeply patriotic book, informed by Republicanism and Social Darwinist racial theories, was widely read and had a profound influence on the revolutionary movement. Thousands of copies of the book were distributed internationally by [[Sun Yat-sen]]<ref name="BergèreLloyd1998">{{cite book|author1=Marie-Claire Bergère|author2=Janet Lloyd|title=Sun Yat-sen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vh7M1u4IGFkC|year=1998|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-4011-1|page=125}}</ref> in support of the revolutionary cause.
Zou found the Qing government unable to deal with the contemporary crisis of colonization, weakness and corruption. For Zou, the Manchu were the source of China's inability to overcome traditional obstacles for modern reforms and he analyzed their mistakes and weaknesses point by point. Moreover, he condemned China's traditional monarchical system, which had made the Han Chinese "slaves" rather than "citizens." He was also influenced by racialist Han ideology, as evidenced in his distaste for the Manchu governing class, as he advocated “annihilation [of] the five million and more of the furry and horned Manchu race, cleansing ourselves of 260 years of harsh and unremitting pain, so that the soil of the Chinese subcontinent is made immaculate, and the descendants of the Yellow Emperor will all become Washingtons.”
His calls for sovereignty of the Chinese people included the establishment of a parliament, equal rights for women, freedom of speech and freedom of the press. These seemingly liberal democratic ideals were underpinned by a potentially genocidal ethnic nationalism; it was not the liberty of the individual, but the sovereignty of the ethnic nation-state ("A man cannot live without his country") that formed the foundations for the Republic of China as envisioned by Zou.
Zou lived in a foreign concession in Shanghai where he enjoyed extraterritorial rights and could not be sentenced to death by a Qing Court. Instead, he was closely associated with [[Zhang Binglin]] and implicated in the [[Subao Case|Subao incident]] as a result, which rendered him a prison sentence of two years; he fell ill while incarcerated and died in April 1905 at the age of 20.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== Zou Rong; Lust, John (trans.): ''The Revolutionary Army : a Chinese Nationalist Tract of 1903.'' Paris: Mouton, 1968.
{{Authority control}}
